==Selected list of songs==
Among Axton's best-known compositions (or co-writing credits) are:
* "Greenback Dollar" - [[cover version|covered by]] [[the Kingston Trio]]  and many others.
* "[[The Pusher]]" - covered by [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]] on their debut album in 1968; this version was also used in the soundtrack of the 1969 film ''[[Easy Rider]]''. [[Nina Simone]] recorded the song in 1971. [[Blind Melon]], [[Isla Grant]], [[Helix (band)|Helix]] and [[The Flaming Lips]] also covered the song.
* "Have a Nice Day" (1971) - covered by [[Bing Crosby]] and [[John Davidson (entertainer)|John Davidson]]
* "Less Than The Song" (1972) - covered by [[Joan Baez]], John Davidson and [[Patti Page]]
* "Lion In The Winter" (1974) - duet with [[Linda Ronstadt]]. Covered by Faan Rousseau Family Band, Isla Grant and Guthrie Girls
* "Southbound" (1975) - covered by [[Three Dog Night]] and [[Commander Cody & His Lost Planet Airmen]]
* "[[No No Song]]" (1975) - became a #3 hit for [[Ringo Starr]] in March 1975
* "[[Never Been to Spain]]" - covered by Three Dog Night, [[Waylon Jennings]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Cher]], and [[Ike & Tina Turner]], and others
* "[[Joy to the World (Three Dog Night song)|Joy to the World]]" - Three Dog Night hit from 1971 that spent six weeks atop the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart. [[Little Richard]] and Matt Axton also covered the song.
* "Snowblind Friend" (1971) - covered by [[Steppenwolf (band)|Steppenwolf]], [[David Allan Coe]], and Chestnut Station
* "Lightning Bar Blues" (1973) - covered by Commander Cody, [[Brownsville Station (band)|Brownsville Station]], [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Arlo Guthrie]] and [[Hanoi Rocks]]
* "Sweet Misery" (1974) - [[cover version|covered by]] [[John Denver]], [[Martha Reeves]], and Matt Axton
* "Sweet Fantasy" (1974) - covered by [[Glen Campbell]] and [[David Clayton-Thomas]]
* "Ease Your Pain" (1971) - covered by [[Bobby Whitlock]], [[Anne Murray]], [[Glenn Yarbrough]] and [[Jackie DeShannon]]
* "[[When the Morning Comes (song)|When the Morning Comes]]" (1974) - duet with [[Linda Ronstadt]]
* "You Taught Me How to Cry" - 1977 duet with [[Tanya Tucker]]. Covered by Matt Axton.
* "Boney Fingers" (1974) - duet with Renee Armand. Armand was co-writer.
* "Jealous Man" (1976) - performed on ''[[WKRP in Cincinnati]]''; covered by [[John Fullbright]]
* "Della and the Dealer" (1979) - also performed on ''WKRP''; reached the top 20 of the ''Billboard'' country chart in the U.S. and the top 50 of the British pop chart
* "Evangelina" (1974) - covered by [[Arlo Guthrie]], [[Albert Lee]], [[Jonathan Edwards (musician)|Jonathan Edwards]], [[Colter Wall]] and others
* "Flash of Fire" (1976) - co-written by [[Cathy Smith]]
* "Gypsy Moth" (1976) - covered by [[Freddie White]] and [[Nathaniel Rateliff]]
* "In a Young Girl's Mind" (1975) - covered by [[Johnny Cash]]

Several songs for the 1977 film ''[[Outlaw Blues]]'' were composed by Axton and sung by [[Peter Fonda]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=85996&category=Full%20Credits |title=Outlaw Blues (1977) – Overview | website=  TCM.com| publisher= Turner Classic Movies| access-date= January 5, 2018}}</ref> 
Axton also contributed songs for the films ''The Legend of Hillbilly John'' (1972), ''[[Buster and Billie]]'' (1974), ''[[Mitchell (film)|Mitchell]]'' (1975), and ''[[The Junkman]]'' (1982).

* ''[[The Midnight Special (TV series)|The Midnight Special]]'' (1973) (musical guest)
* ''The Hoyt Axton Country Western Boogie Woogie Gospel Rock and Roll Show'' (1975) – Himself. NBC TV special featuring Linda Ronstadt, Arlo Guthrie and Ringo Starr.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2759452/| publisher= IMDb| title=The Hoyt Axton Country Western Boogie Woogie Gospel Rock and Roll Show|access-date= August 26, 2019}}</ref>
* ''[[The Bionic Woman]]'' (1976) – Buck Buckley
* ''[[Dinah!]]'' (1976) (musical guest)
* ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'' (1977) – Johnny Starbuck
* ''[[Hee Haw]]'' (1977) (musical guest)
* ''[[Flying High (TV series)|Flying High]]'' (1978) - Himself
* ''Hee Haw Honeys'' (1979) (musical guest)
* ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' (1979) (musical guest)
* ''[[WKRP in Cincinnati]]'' (1979, performed "Della and the Dealer" and "Jealous Man") – T.J. Watson
* ''[[Austin City Limits]]'' (1979)  (musical guest)
* ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]'' (1981)  (musical guest)
* ''[[Flo (TV series)|Flo]]'' (1981) - Himself
* ''[[Barbara Mandrell & the Mandrell Sisters]]'' (1981) (musical guest)
* ''Seven Brides for Seven Brothers'' (1982, Season 1, Episode 3: "Challenges," and Episode 8: "Rodeo", in which he sang "I Dream of Highways") – Cooper Johnson
* ''[[The Rousters]]'' (1983–1984) – Cactus Jack Slade
* ''[[Diff'rent Strokes]]'' (1984-1985) – Wes McKinney
* ''[[Domestic Life (TV series)|Domestic Life]]'' (1984) – Rip Steele
* ''[[Faerie Tale Theatre]]'' (1984, "[[Goldilocks and the Three Bears (Faerie Tale Theatre episode)|Goldilocks and the Three Bears]]") – Forest Ranger
* ''[[Cover Up (TV series)|Cover Up]]'' (1984) - John Cody
* ''[[Glitter (American TV series)|Glitter]]'' (1985) - Christie's father
* ''The Steel Collar Man'' (series pilot, 1985) - Red
* ''[[Trapper John, M.D.]]'' (1985) - Jack Dearborne
* ''[[Dallas: The Early Years]]'' (1986, TV Movie) – Aaron Southworth
* ''[[Murder, She Wrote]]'' (1988) – Sheriff Tate
* ''[[Midnight Caller]]'' (1990) – Ralston Cash Dollar 
* ''[[Growing Pains]]'' (1990) – Claver Jackson
* ''[[Railfair 91]]'' (1991, VHS Documentary) - Guest Host and Musical Guest
* ''[[Doorways]]'' (1993, series pilot) - Jake Mitchell


In 1992 Axton narrated ''The Alaska Highway: 1942-1992'' a documentary about the history of the [[Alaska Highway]] that was produced by public television station [[KAKM]] of [[Anchorage, Alaska|Anchorage]] and shown nationally on [[PBS]]. In the mid-1990s, Axton was chosen to host and narrate the profile series ''[[Life and Times (TV series)|Life and Times]]'' on [[The Nashville Network]], in which a different country music figure was spotlighted each hour. His voice was heard throughout and he was seen on camera doing the introduction and closing of each show in which he participated.

Axton also served as the narrator for two documentaries about the [[Western States Endurance Run|Western States Endurance Race]] in 1982 and 1983 titled ''Desperate Dreams''.

'''Hunter Easton Hayes''' (born September 9, 1991)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/hunter-hayes-celebrates-his-20th-birthday-at-house-of-blues|title=Hunter Hayes Celebrates His 20th Birthday at House of Blues|author=Dan Harr|work=Music News Nashville|date=September 14, 2011|access-date=September 14, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110064648/http://www.musicnewsnashville.com/hunter-hayes-celebrates-his-20th-birthday-at-house-of-blues|archive-date=November 10, 2011|url-status=dead}}</ref> is an American multi-genre singer, songwriter, record producer, and multi-instrumentalist. He is proficient at more than 30 instruments.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6077406/hunter-hayes-leads-country-youth-revolution-storyline-video-interview|title=Hunter Hayes Leads Country's Youth Revolution, Without a Pickup Truck or Beer in Sight|author=Deborah Evans Price|magazine=Billboard|date=May 6, 2014|access-date=May 6, 2014}}</ref>

Hayes released his [[Hunter Hayes (album)|self-titled debut album]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-debut-album/ |title=Hunter Hayes Sets Release Date for Debut Album |work=Taste of Country |date=August 24, 2011 |access-date=November 7, 2011 |first=Amanda |last=Hensel}}</ref> It reached number seven on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number one on the [[Top Country Albums]], and sold over 1.1 million copies. Its most successful single, "[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]", sold over 3.5 million copies and made Hayes the youngest male act to ever top the [[Hot Country Songs|''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs]].

Hayes' commercial success and his talent both as a songwriter and instrumentalist prompted ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' to call him the leader of "Country Music's Youth Revolution" in 2014.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6077406/hunter-hayes-leads-country-youth-revolution-storyline-video-interview |title=Hunter Hayes Leads Country's Youth Revolution, Without a Pickup Truck or Beer in Sight |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=May 6, 2014}}</ref> He has been nominated for five [[Grammy Award]]s including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]], and won the 2012 [[CMA Award]] for [[Country Music Association Award for New Artist of the Year|New Artist of the Year]] and three [[Broadcast Music, Inc.|BMI Awards]].

==Life and career==
Hayes was born on September 9, 1991, in [[Breaux Bridge, Louisiana]]; he is an only child.<ref>[http://www.hunterhayes.com/bio Hunter's Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209104810/http://www.hunterhayes.com/bio |date=February 9, 2012 }}. HunterHayes.com. Retrieved on February 21, 2012.</ref> His parents both have [[Cajuns|Cajun]] ancestry, along with [[English people|English]], [[Scotch-Irish Americans|Scots-Irish]], and [[Germans|German]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0371048/bio?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm#trivia|title=Hunter Hayes : Biography|publisher=IMDb.com|access-date=May 10, 2014}}</ref> He grew up [[Catholic Church|Catholic]], singing songs in both English and French.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20123577,00.html |title=Squeeze Play |journal=People |first=Jeremy |last=Helligar |date=October 27, 1997 |volume=48 |issue=17 |page=113 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-date=April 21, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421054547/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20123577,00.html |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Wilkinson |first=Hannah |title=You Are Good Enough: Hunter Hayes and Jen Ledger Find Their Value In Christ |url=https://www.jesuscalling.com/podcast/good-enough-hunter-hayes-jen-ledger-find-value-christ/ |access-date=2022-08-14 |website=Jesus Calling |date=August 16, 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref>

Hayes started performing when he was 2. At 4, he began making appearances locally and on national television,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iz0dAAAAIBAJ&pg=5100,573829&dq=hunter-hayes+accordion&hl=en|title=Kids keep Cajun traditions thriving|last=Rose|first=Christopher|date=April 4, 1997|work=The Tuscaloosa News|access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-music-interview-2011/|title=Hunter Hayes Was 'Born' to Make Country Music|last=Conaway|first=Alanna|work=Taste of Country|date=June 13, 2011 |access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref> including ''[[Maury (TV series)|Maury]]'', ''[[Rosie O'Donnell Show]]'', and the [[Nickelodeon]] game show ''[[Figure It Out]]'', where he performed "[[Jambalaya (On the Bayou)]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mPpjNgdT2dk/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211219/mPpjNgdT2dk |archive-date=2021-12-19 |url-status=live|title=Hunter Hayes - "Jambalaya" on Figure it Out|website=[[YouTube]]|date=October 16, 2011 |access-date=August 1, 2012}}{{cbignore}}</ref> [[American Songwriter]] writes that "Hayes received his first guitar from actor [[Robert Duvall]] at age 6"<ref name="American Songwriter">{{cite magazine|url=http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/05/hunter-hayes-is-martin-guitars-latest-brand-ambassador/ |title=Hunter Hayes Is Martin Guitars' Latest Brand Ambassador |magazine=American Songwriter |author=Evan Schlansky |date=May 21, 2012 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128022554/http://www.americansongwriter.com/2012/05/hunter-hayes-is-martin-guitars-latest-brand-ambassador/ |archive-date=January 28, 2013 |access-date=June 6, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> At age 7, he was invited to perform for President [[Bill Clinton]] for a [[White House]] lawn party. At 13, he appeared on [[America's Most Talented Kids]], a show hosted by [[Dave Coulier]]; he performed the hit [[Hank Williams]] song, "[[Hey Good Lookin' (song)|Hey Good Lookin']]". At age 9, Hunter released his debut independent studio album ''"Through My Eyes"'' on October 8, 2000, under Suagartown Records and Louisiana Red Hot Records.<ref>{{cite web|title=Through My Eyes - Hunter Hayes {{!}} Songs, Reviews, Credits {{!}} AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/through-my-eyes-mw0000053846|website=AllMusic|access-date=29 December 2017}}</ref> He released several more independent albums: ''Make a Wish'' in 2001, ''Holidays with Hunter'' in 2003, ''Honoring our French Heritage'' in 2006, and ''Songs About Nothing'' in 2008.

In 2008, he moved from Breaux Bridge to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], and signed with [[Universal Music Publishing Group]] as a songwriter. In 2010, Hayes co-wrote "Play" for the [[Rascal Flatts]] album ''[[Nothing Like This (album)|Nothing Like This]]''. In September, he was signed to [[Atlantic Records]] Nashville and began working on what would become his major-label debut.

Hayes appeared as the opening act of 10 dates of country star [[Taylor Swift]]'s [[Speak Now World Tour]] throughout the summer of 2011 and concluded his leg of the tour in St. Louis, Missouri.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-will-open-taylor-swift-speak-now-north-american-tour-2011 |title=Hunter Hayes will open for Taylor Swift SPEAK NOW North American Tour 2011 |work=HunterHayes.com |date=March 4, 2011 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506142749/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-will-open-taylor-swift-speak-now-north-american-tour-2011 |archive-date=May 6, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In April 2011, he went on his own radio tour where he debuted songs that would appear on his debut album.<ref name="radiotour">{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mpNAs08ZcVc  |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211219/mpNAs08ZcVc |archive-date=2021-12-19 |url-status=live|title=Hunter Hayes – Radio Tour (Week 1) |access-date=October 30, 2011 |author=Hunter Hayes |website=[[YouTube]] |date=April 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> His debut headlining tour was the Most Wanted Tour; the first leg of the tour began on October 8, 2011, in [[Beaumont, Texas]], and ended on December 4, 2011, in [[San Bernardino, California]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-2011-tour-dates/ |title=Hunter Hayes Sets Fall 2011 Tour Dates |work=Taste of Country |date=September 13, 2011 |access-date=November 7, 2011 |first=Alanna |last=Conaway}}</ref>

Hayes and singer [[Victoria Justice]] contributed a duet to the soundtrack of 2011's ''[[Footloose (2011 film)|Footloose]]'' remake, recording a cover of [[Mike Reno]]'s and [[Ann Wilson]]'s 1984 hit "[[Almost Paradise (song)|Almost Paradise]]" from the original film. From January to February 2012, Hayes was the opening act on the [[Rascal Flatts]] "Thaw Out" tour.<ref>[http://www.rascalflatts.com/story/news/rascal-flatts-announce-ithaw-out-2012i-tour Rascal Flatts Announce Thaw Out 2012 Tour]. RascalFlatts.com (October 17, 2011). Retrieved on February 21, 2012.</ref>
[[File:Hunter Hayes.jpg|thumb|Hayes signing autographs in [[Frederick, Maryland]] in August 2012]]

"Where We Left Off" is an original song, written by Hayes, that can be heard on the [[Act of Valor: The Album|soundtrack]] for the 2012 war film ''[[Act of Valor]]''.<ref>[http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/entertainment/53539733-81/act-valor-original-songs.html.csp 'Act of Valor' soundtrack features original songs from Lady Antebellum, more]. Sltrib.com (February 20, 2012). Retrieved on 2012-02-21.</ref>

During the 2012 [[O Music Awards]], [[The Flaming Lips]] broke a [[Guinness World Record]] (previously held by [[Jay-Z]]) for most concerts played in multiple cities in a 24-hr. period. Hayes was the opening act for them at the Hattiesburg stop.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1688734/hunter-hayes-performs-on-o-music-awards.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105061428/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1688734/hunter-hayes-performs-on-o-music-awards.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 5, 2012 |title=Hunter Hayes Performs on O Music Awards |work=[[Country Music Television]] |date=June 28, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref>

In May 2012, [[Martin Guitars]] named Hayes as C.F. Martin & Co.'s newest brand ambassador. [[American Songwriter]] quoted Hayes on the subject: "It is an absolute honor to be named an official Martin Ambassador and to be recognized by the Martin family."<ref name="American Songwriter"/>

On September 7, 2012, he was inducted at the [[Mahalia Jackson Theater]] in [[New Orleans|New Orleans, Louisiana]], into the [[Louisiana Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/hunter-hayes-inducted-louisiana-music-194054387.html |title=Hunter Hayes Inducted Into Louisiana Music Hall of Fame |work=[[Yahoo! Finance]] |date=September 10, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref>

===2011–2014: ''Hunter Hayes'' and ''Storyline''===
[[File:Hunter Hayes Gettysburg, PA.png|thumb|Hayes performing in 2013]]
[[File:Five-time Grammy nominee Hunter Hayes performs his national anthem soundcheck, hours before Game 6 of the World Series. (30415750290).jpg|thumbnail|Hayes doing a soundcheck at [[Progressive Field]] in preparation for his performance of the [[Star Spangled Banner|US national anthem]] at Game 6 of the [[2016 World Series]]]]

Hayes's debut single, "[[Storm Warning (song)|Storm Warning]]", released to radio on May 16, 2011. His [[Hunter Hayes (album)|self-titled]] major-label debut album was released on October 11, 2011.<ref>[http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-release-self-titled-debut-album-atlantic-records-october-11 HUNTER HAYES TO RELEASE SELF-TITLED DEBUT ALBUM ON ATLANTIC RECORDS OCTOBER 11] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220175525/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-release-self-titled-debut-album-atlantic-records-october-11 |date=February 20, 2012 }}. HunterHayes.com (August 24, 2011). Retrieved on 2012-02-21.</ref> He co-wrote every song, played every instrument, and along with Dann Huff, produced the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=5319|title=Hunter Hayes becomes Next Big Thing|date=April 22, 2011|work=Country Standard Time|access-date=June 30, 2011}}</ref> "[[Wanted (Hunter Hayes song)|Wanted]]", the second single, was released to radio on March 5, 2012.

On July 24, 2012, he appeared on the CBS's ''The Talk'', where he was then given an RIAA Gold Certification plaque for "Wanted".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunters-interview-and-performance-talk |title=Hunter's Interview And Performance On The Talk |work=HunterHayes.com |date=July 25, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015165352/http://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunters-interview-and-performance-talk |archive-date=October 15, 2012 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Just shy of two months since "Wanted" went gold, the song was certified Platinum by RIAA on August 23, 2012.

"Wanted" became his first No. 1 single,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-wanted-no-1-single/ |title=Hunter Hayes Gets What He 'Wanted' With First No. 1 Single |work=Taste of Country |date=September 18, 2012 |first=Alanna |last=Conaway |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> making him the youngest solo male act to top Hot Country Songs, breaking the record set in 1973 by [[Johnny Rodriguez]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/475001/hunter-hayes-makes-history-little-big-town-shines-on-country-charts |title=Hunter Hayes Makes History, Little Big Town Shines on Country Charts |magazine=Billboard |date=September 20, 2012 |first=Wade |last=Jessen |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> Twenty weeks after first appearing in the top spot and under a new chart format, "Wanted" returned to the top spot.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/1539423/ask-billboard-whats-so-unusual-about-hunter-hayes-new-no-1/ |title=Ask Billboard: What's so unusual about Hunter Hayes's New No. 1 |magazine=Billboard |first=Gary |last=Trust |date=February 18, 2013 |access-date=May 2, 2013}}</ref> "[[Somebody's Heartbreak]]", the album's third single, went to No. 1 on the [[Country Airplay]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Hunter Hayes Dupe 1 - Chart History (Country Airplay)|url= https://www.billboard.com/artist/hunter-hayes-dupe-1/chart-history/csa/ |magazine=Billboard|accessdate=February 11, 2023}}</ref>

Starting September 14, 2012, Hayes began appearing as the opening act on 90+ dates for [[Carrie Underwood]]'s [[Blown Away Tour]].

He was also nominated for three Grammys including [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] at the [[2013 Grammy Awards]]; he is the youngest male country artist to be nominated in all three categories for which he was nominated.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.billboardhcom/articles/columns/the-615/1538011/hunter-hayes-my-grammy-ritual |title=Hunter Hayes: My Grammy Ritual |magazine=Billboard |date=February 6, 2013 |first=Matt |last=Diehl |access-date=May 2, 2013 }}{{Dead link|date=January 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=About Hunter Hayes|url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/hunter-hayes/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121220034549/http://www.cmt.com/artists/hunter-hayes/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 20, 2012|access-date=March 16, 2013}}</ref> The album's fourth single, "[[I Want Crazy]]", which is from the deluxe ''Encore'' edition, was released to country radio on April 7, 2013. It peaked at number two on the Country Airplay chart in August 2013. Following it was "[[Everybody's Got Somebody but Me]]", a re-recording of a song from the original press of the album. The re-recorded version features guest vocals from [[Jason Mraz]].

Hunter was one of five country singers who won a CMT Artist of the Year award in 2013. This award is awarded every year to a group of country musicians who have had an outstanding year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1718091/hunter-hayes-interview-cmt-artists-of-the-year.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131130075801/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1718091/hunter-hayes-interview-cmt-artists-of-the-year.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=November 30, 2013 |title=News : Hunter Hayes Interview: CMT Artists of the Year |publisher=CMT |date=November 28, 2013 |access-date=May 9, 2014}}</ref>

Hayes performed "[[Invisible (Hunter Hayes song)|Invisible]]", the lead single from his second album, at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Craig Shelburne |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1721157/hunter-hayes-debuts-invisible-on-grammys.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140129074928/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1721157/hunter-hayes-debuts-invisible-on-grammys.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 29, 2014 |title=News : Hunter Hayes Debuts "Invisible" on Grammys |publisher=CMT |date=January 26, 2014 |access-date=May 9, 2014}}</ref> ''[[Storyline (Hunter Hayes album)|Storyline]]'' was released on May 6, 2014.<ref name="news.radio.com">{{cite web |url=http://news.radio.com/2014/03/11/hunter-hayes-new-album-storyline-to-drop-may-6/ |title=Hunter Hayes' New Album 'Storyline' to Drop May 6 « Radio.com |publisher=News.radio.com |date=March 11, 2014 |access-date=May 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140321031056/http://news.radio.com/2014/03/11/hunter-hayes-new-album-storyline-to-drop-may-6/ |archive-date=March 21, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> In an effort to promote his album and to raise awareness to end child hunger, Hunter broke the Guinness World Record for the most concerts played in multiple cities in 24 hours, previously held by [[The Flaming Lips]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-615/6084729/hunter-hayes-breaks-the-flaming-lips-guinness-world-record-while-raising-awareness-most-concerts-played-in-multiple-cities-in-24-hours-conagra-Foods |title=Hunter Hayes Breaks Guinness World Record For Most Concerts Played in multiple cities in 24 hours |magazine=Billboard |date=May 10, 2014 |access-date=August 9, 2014}}</ref> The album's second single, "[[Tattoo (Hunter Hayes song)|Tattoo]]" released to country radio on June 16, 2014.

On July 20, 2014, Hayes's self-titled debut album was certified double platinum by the RIAA.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&ar=Hunter+Hayes&ti=Hunter+Hayes#search_section|title=Gold & Platinum - RIAA|website=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]}}</ref> Following that was "[[Light Me Up (Hunter Hayes song)|Light Me Up]]", another single from the deluxe version of his debut album, in 2015.

===2015–2018: ''The 21 Project'' and canceled album===
On May 21, 2015, Hayes released "[[21 (Hunter Hayes song)|21]]", which was the title track for both his EP and third studio album, [[The 21 Project]]. He also appeared on the track "I Can Play Guitar" on [[Brett Kissel]]'s album ''[[Pick Me Up (album)|Pick Me Up]]''.

On November 2, 2016, Hayes performed with four holograms of himself on Jimmy Kimmel Live's after the CMA show.

In March 2017, Hayes performed as part of the [[C2C: Country to Country]] festival in the UK where he played alongside [[Dan + Shay]] and [[Darius Rucker]] supporting [[Reba McEntire]] and would return in 2019 with [[Carly Pearce]] and [[Dustin Lynch]] in support of [[Lady A]]. Following "21," Hayes released several songs including “[[Yesterday's Song|Yesterday’s Song]]” which were slated to be part of a studio album set to be released in February 2018. Hayes then canceled the project citing “shifted priorities.”<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8527354/hunter-hayes-wild-blue-interview|title=Hunter Hayes on His New Album, 'Wild Blue': 'What This Record Did for Me Was Something Pretty Profound'|first= Melinda |last=Newman |date= August 14, 2019 |magazine=Billboard }}</ref>

Hayes also appeared as a guest star in the Nickelodeon show ''Bella and the Bulldogs''.{{Citation needed|date=July 2019}}

===2018–present: ''Wild Blue'' and ''Red Sky''===
{{see also|Red Sky (Hunter Hayes album) }}
In December 2018, Hayes guest starred on ''[[Darci Lynne]]: My Hometown Christmas''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Delbel|first1=Julia|title=Star-Studded Lineup Revealed for 'Darci Lynne: A Hometown Christmas'|url=https://talentrecap.com/got-talent/agt/2018/10/20/star-studded-lineup-revealed-darci-lynne-hometown-christmas/|work=Talent Recap|date=20 October 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181022232716/https://talentrecap.com/got-talent/agt/2018/10/20/star-studded-lineup-revealed-darci-lynne-hometown-christmas/|archive-date=October 22, 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also recorded a duet with Irish singer [[Catherine McGrath]] for her debut album ''[[Talk of This Town (album)|Talk of This Town]]''.

In January 2019, Hayes released his first radio single in three years titled "Heartbreak" which was the lead single for an upcoming album to be released by [[Warner Music Nashville]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Future Releases for Country Radio Stations
|url=https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |website=All Access Media |access-date=February 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190216014058/https://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases |archive-date=February 16, 2019}}</ref> Hayes headlined the [[Closer to You Tour]] in 2019 with [[Levi Hummon]] and [[Tegan Marie]] as supporting acts.<ref>{{cite web|last=Krol|first=Jacklyn|title= Hunter Hayes Sets Spring 2019 Closer to You Tour|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-21-tour-fall-2015/ |publisher=Taste of Country|date=August 14, 2015|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Casey|first=Jim|title= Hunter Hayes Drops New Single & Will Hit the Road for "Closer to You" Tour |url= https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2019/03/25/hunter-hayes-drops-new-single-will-hit-the-road-for-closer-to-you-tour/|website=The Country Daily|publisher=Cumulus Media|date=March 25, 2019|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hollabaugh|first=Lorie|url= https://musicrow.com/2019/02/hunter-hayes-to-launch-closer-to-you-tour-in-april/|title= Hunter Hayes to Launch Closer to You Tour in April|work=MusicRow Magazine|date=February 7, 2019|access-date=24 June 2020}}</ref>

In August 2019, Hayes made a surprise announcement on [[NBC|NBC's]] [[Today (American TV program)|Today Show]] revealing his album ''[[Wild Blue (Part I)]]'' would be released on August 16, 2019.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.hunterhayes.com/news/hunter-hayes-soars-new-album-wild-blue-part-i-6956|title=HUNTER HAYES SOARS ON NEW ALBUM "WILD BLUE (PART I)"|date= August 14, 2019 |work=Warner Music Nashville}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2019/08/14/hunter-hayes-shares-heartbreak-growth-new-album-wild-blue/1948649001/|title=Hunter Hayes to drop 'Wild Blue,' surprise album of heartbreak, turbulence|first=Cindy |last=Watts |date= August 14, 2019 |work=The Tennessean}}</ref> The album is the first part of a three-part ‘trilogy’ of albums.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hunter-hayes-wild-blue/|title=HUNTER HAYES ANNOUNCES 'WILD BLUE' ALBUM, RELEASES TITLE TRACK [LISTEN]|first= Jacklyn |last=Krol |date= August 14, 2019 |work=Taste of Country }}</ref>

In April 2020, Hayes competed in the [[The Masked Singer (American TV series) season 3|third season]] of ''[[The Masked Singer (American TV series)|The Masked Singer]]'' as "Astronaut".<ref>{{Cite web | url=https://variety.com/2020/tv/news/the-masked-singer-season-3-episode-14-recap-astronaut-1234593561/ |title = 'The Masked Singer' Reveals the Identity of the Astronaut: Here's the Star Under the Mask|date = April 30, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1146480/the-masked-singer-unmasks-the-astronaut |title = The Masked Singer Unmasks the Astronaut|date = April 30, 2020}}</ref> In June 2020, the [[Saskatchewan]]-based [[Hunter Brothers]] released their single "[[Hard Dirt]]", co-written and produced by Hayes.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://openroadrecordings.com/news/hunter-brothers-drop-highly-anticipated-new-single-hard-dirt-june-12/ |title=Hunter Brothers drop highly-anticipated new single "Hard Dirt" June 12 |date=June 5, 2020 |access-date=June 11, 2020 |work=[[Open Road Recordings]] }}{{Dead link|date=August 2024 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> He also co-wrote and produced their 2021 single "[[Been a Minute]]".<ref>{{cite news|first=Nanci|last=Dagg|url=https://canadianbeats.ca/2021/03/20/timing-is-everything-and-the-time-couldnt-be-more-perfect-for-the-hunter-brothers-to-release-their-new-single-been-a-minute/|title= Timing is everything and the time couldn't be more perfect for the Hunter Brothers to release their new single "Been a Minute"|date=March 20, 2021|access-date=March 22, 2021|work=Canadian Beats Media}}</ref>

In October 2021, Hayes released the album ''Wild Blue Complete'' an extension of the album ''Wild Blue (Part I)''.<ref>{{Cite web|title="Wild Blue Complete"|url=https://www.hunterhayes.com/news/wild-blue-complete|access-date=2022-01-09|website=Hunter Hayes|language=en-US}}</ref>

In April 2023, Hayes released the album ''[[Red Sky (Hunter Hayes album)|Red Sky]].''<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fisher |first=Kelly |date=21 April 2023 |title=Hunter Hayes Unleashes Long-Awaited 'Red Sky' After Years In The Making |url=https://country.iheart.com/content/2023-04-21-hunter-hayes-unleashes-long-awaited-red-sky-after-years-in-the-making/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230421180104/https://country.iheart.com/content/2023-04-21-hunter-hayes-unleashes-long-awaited-red-sky-after-years-in-the-making/ |archive-date=21 April 2023 |access-date=2023-07-10 |website=iHeartCountry Radio |language=en}}</ref>

==Awards and nominations==
{{BLP sources section|date=October 2018}}

===Academy of Country Music Awards===
The [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], also known as the ACM Awards, were first held in 1966, honoring the industry's accomplishments during the previous year. It was the first country music awards program held by a major organization. The academy's signature "hat" trophy was created in 1968. The awards were first televised in 1972 on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]].

===American Country Awards===
The [[American Country Awards]] is a country music awards show, entirely voted on by fans. Created by the Fox Network, the awards honor country music artists in music, video, and touring categories. Hayes has won two awards from five nominations.

===Grammy Awards===
A [[Grammy Award]] (originally called '''Gramophone Award'''), or '''Grammy''', is an accolade by the [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] (NARAS) of the United States to recognize outstanding achievement in the [[music industry]]. The annual presentation ceremony features performances by prominent artists, and the presentation of those awards that have a more popular interest.

[[File:Jasmine Rae - Heartbeat (Official Music Video).webm|thumb|Jasmine Rae performing "Heartbeat".]]

'''Jasmine Rae''' is an Australian singer and songwriter who has released five studio albums via [[ABC Music]] Australia. Rae has been nominated for four [[ARIA Music Awards]] and has won two [[CMC Music Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jasminerae.com.au/news.cfm |title=Jasmine Rae – Listen Here: Official Website |accessdate=21 June 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701122234/http://www.jasminerae.com.au/news.cfm |archivedate=1 July 2011  }}</ref> and received the 'Global Artist of the Year' award by the US [[Country Music Association]] in 2013. She is also an eleven-time Golden Guitar nominee.

==Biography==
===2008–2010: Telstra Road to Tamworth and ''Look It Up'' ===
In 2008, Rae auditioned for and won the Telstra Road to Tamworth.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.beinvolved.com.au/spo-arts-a-community/country-music/road-to-tamworth-previous-winners |title=Telstra Road to Tamworth - Previous Winners |access-date=6 February 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712060217/http://www.beinvolved.com.au/spo-arts-a-community/country-music/road-to-tamworth-previous-winners |archive-date=12 July 2010 |url-status=dead  }}</ref> Her prize was a recording contract with [[ABC Music]] and a performance at the 2008 CMA music festival in [[Nashville]].

Rae recorded and release her debut studio album ''[[Look It Up (album)|Look It Up]]'' in September 2008. The title track, "[[Look It Up (song)|Look It Up]]" was later covered by American country artist [[Ashton Shepherd]], which become a Top 20 hit on the U.S. ''Billboard'' Hot Country Songs chart.

In 2009, Rae toured with [[Brooks & Dunn]].

===2011–2012: ''Listen Here'' ===
In March 2011, Rae released her second studio album ''[[Listen Here (Jasmine Rae album)|Listen Here]]''. The album debuted at No. 1 on the ARIA Australian Artists Country Chart and No. 35 on the ARIA Albums Chart. Two singles "Hunky Country Boys" and "I'll Try Anything" topped the Australian Country airplay charts.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}} Those songs plus "I Faked It" also went to No. 1 on the CMC Music Video chart. The album was nominated for the [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.destinationnsw.com.au/news-and-media/media-releases/2011-aria-awards-nominations-announced|title=2011 ARIA Awards nominations announced {{!}} Destination NSW|website=www.destinationnsw.com.au|language=en-AU|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref> Jasmine was also a Golden Guitar nominee for Female Artist of the Year at the Australian Country Music Awards the following January.

In 2012 Australian Music fans voted Jasmine Rae, CMC OZ Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/the-cmc-awards-winners |title=Country Music News - Latest local and international country music news &#124; Country Music Channel |access-date=10 September 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324161514/http://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/pages/main-menu/news/latest-news/the-cmc-awards-winners |archive-date=24 March 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> She remains the only female solo artist to ever win the award. In November 2012, Rae released a Christmas EP titled ''[[Santa's Little Helper (EP)|Santa's Little Helper]]''.

In 2013 she received a CMA Award (US) for Global Artist of the Year<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thewest.com.au/entertainment/music/country-starlet-is-boss-of-her-domain-ng-ya-358206|title=Jasmine Rae|date=2 September 2013|work=The West Australian|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>

===2013–2014: ''If I Want To'' ===
In August 2013, Rae released her third studio album ''[[If I Want To]]''; the title track shot straight to the top of the CMC Top 30 Countdown chart and held strong for four weeks. The track also topped the Australian Country Radio charts. ''[[If I Want To]]'' was nominated for ARIA Award for Best Country Album.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/aria-awards-2013-nominees-revealed-fine-arts-award-winners-announced/#/slide/1|title=ARIA Awards 2013 Nominees Revealed, Fine Arts Award Winners Announced – Music Feeds|date=1 October 2013|work=Music Feeds|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> and four Golden Guitar Awards at the 2014 CMA Awards; for Album of the Year, Top Selling Album of the Year, Single of the Year and Female Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.northernstar.com.au/news/lee-kernaghan-leads-2014-golden-guitar-nominations/2084025/|title=Lee Kernaghan leads the 2014 Golden Guitar nominations|last=Cronin|first=Seanna|work=Northern Star|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en}}</ref>

In March 2014, Jasmine Rae won her second CMC Music Award for 'Female Oz Artist of the Year.'<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/morgan-evans-wins-big-at-the-cmc-awards|title=Morgan Evans wins big at the CMC Awards {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=1 March 2014|work=Country Music Channel|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Rae featured on [[Adam Brand (musician)|Adam Brand]]'s song "Quit This Time"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2prEUwvmQ70 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/2prEUwvmQ70 |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|title=Jasmine Rae & Adam Brand – Quit This Time (Music Video)|last=Jasmine Rae|date=30 September 2014|publisher=|via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> from Brand's album ''[[My Side of the Street]]'' which was released in August 2014.

===2015–2019: ''Heartbeat'' ===
Rae released her fourth album, titled ''[[Heartbeat (Jasmine Rae album)|Heartbeat]]'' through ABC Music / Universal Music Australia on 15 May 2015. The single "Heartbeat" became her ninth number-one Australian country single<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jasminerae.com/#!heartbeartno1radio/csca|title=JASMINE RAE – OFFICIAL WEBSITE – Singer/Songwriter, Actor, Entertainer|website=jasminerae.com}}</ref> and "When I Found You": – a song she originally wrote for her best friends wedding has been viewed more than 10 million times on YouTube.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jasmine Rae|title=Jasmine Rae – When I Found You (Official Music Video)|website=[[YouTube]]|date=1 November 2015|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-T-aSHM0fc |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211220/L-T-aSHM0fc |archive-date=2021-12-20 |url-status=live|access-date=20 August 2018}}{{cbignore}}</ref> "Everybody Wants to Take My Money" was a finalist in the 2016 International Songwriting Competition.

''Heartbeat'' was nominated for two Golden Guitar awards in 2016 and Jasmine was again nominated for CMC 'Female Oz Artist of the Year' in 2016<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.countrymusicchannel.com.au/2016-cmc-music-awards-finalists-announced|title=2016 CMC Music Awards finalists announced {{!}} Country Music Channel on Foxtel|date=3 March 2016|work=Country Music Channel|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> and 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.workingbull.com.au/news/cmc-music-awards-2017-finalists/|title=CMC Music Awards 2017: Finalists • Working Bull Pty Ltd|date=1 March 2017|work=Working Bull Pty Ltd|access-date=20 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Like ''[[If I Want To]]'', the album was produced by Luke Wooten.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://themusic.com.au/music/streams/2015/05/12/jasmine-rae-heartbeat/|title=EXCLUSIVE: Jasmine Rae – Heartbeat|website=theMusic|language=en-GB|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>

In 2018, Jasmine toured with US country singer [[Granger Smith]]<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.northerndailyleader.com.au/story/5626945/why-2018-has-been-a-roller-coaster-ride-for-jasmine-rae/ |title=Jasmine Rae reflects on Granger Smith tour success and When I Found You court battle|newspaper=The Northern Daily Leader |date=4 September 2018}}</ref> and began writing for a new album.

In 2019, Jasmine released the singles "Right Now" and "Party on the Couch"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/country/jasmine-rae-and-friends-enjoy-a-party-on-the-couch/|title=Jasmine Rae and friends enjoy a 'Party On The Couch' - Tone Country|accessdate=16 May 2023}}</ref>—her first official music video in over two and a half years.

Jasmine has also been announced as an artist on the 2020 CMC Rocks QLD line-up.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://themusic.com.au/news/cmc-rocks-qld-2020-line-up/rZO1oaCjoqU/ | title=Miranda Lambert, Kip Moore & Morgan Evans Lead CMC Rocks QLD 2020 Line-up }}</ref>

===2020–present: ''Lion Side'' ===
In 2020 Jasmine released the new singles "Green Light" and "Don't Do It for the Haters" plus the album ''Lion Side''. The album was nominated for the ARIA Award for Best Country Album<ref>{{Cite web|title=ARIA Awards 2020 Nominees|url=https://www.aria.com.au/awards/nominees|access-date=2021-02-02|website=www.aria.com.au|language=en}}</ref> and the album peaked at #11 on the ARIA Albums chart, #2 on the AIR Independent Albums chart and #1 on the ARIA Australian Country Albums chart. Jasmine was also nominated for 'Female Artist of the Year' and 'Contemporary Country Album of the Year' at the 2021 Golden Guitar Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title=2021 Golden Guitar Nominees Revealed|url=https://www.kixcountry.com.au/country-confidential/47957-2021-golden-guitar-nominees-revealed-updating|access-date=2021-02-02|website=www.kixcountry.com.au|date=19 November 2020|language=en-gb}}</ref>

==Awards==
===ARIA Music Awards===
The [[ARIA Music Awards]] are a set of annual ceremonies presented by [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), which recognise excellence, innovation, and achievement across all genres of the [[music of Australia]]. They commenced in 1987. Rae has been nominated for four [[ARIA Music Awards]], all in the category [[ARIA Award for Best Country Album|Best Country Album]].<ref name="ARIA 2020 Wins">{{cite web | url = https://www.aria.com.au/awards/news/and-the-2020-aria-award-goes-to | title = And the 2020 ARIA Awards Go To… | publisher = Australian Recording Industry Association (ARIA) | access-date = 3 December 2020 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20201126005048/https://www.aria.com.au/awards/news/and-the-2020-aria-award-goes-to | archive-date = 26 November 2020 | url-status = live }}</ref>
