'''John Clayton Mayer'''<ref name=allmusicbio>{{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-mayer-mn0000239827/biography|title=John Mayer Biography|first=Andrew|last=Leahey|publisher=[[AllMusic.com]]|access-date=October 25, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026001533/https://www.allmusic.com/artist/john-mayer-mn0000239827/biography|archive-date=October 26, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|m|eɪ|.|ɚ}} {{Respell|MAY|ər}}; born October 16, 1977) is an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hoard |first1=Joel |title=John Mayer: Biography |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/john-mayer/biography |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=March 18, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826142006/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/john-mayer/biography |archive-date=August 26, 2017 |date=2001}}</ref> He attended [[Berklee College of Music]] in [[Boston]], but he left for [[Atlanta]] in 1997 with fellow guitarist [[Clay Cook]], with whom he formed the short-lived rock duo, Lo-Fi Masters. After their split, Mayer continued to play at local clubs, refining his skills and gaining a minor following. He performed at the 2000 [[South by Southwest]] festival, and was subsequently signed by [[Aware Records]], an imprint of [[Columbia Records]] through which he released his debut [[extended play]] (EP), ''[[Inside Wants Out]]'' (1999). His first two studio albums—''[[Room for Squares]]'' (2001) and ''[[Heavier Things]]'' (2003)—were both met with critical and commercial success; the former won a [[Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance]] for its single "[[Your Body Is a Wonderland]]", while the latter peaked atop the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]].

By 2005, Mayer had moved away from the acoustic music that characterized his early records, and further delved into the [[blues]] and rock music which had originally influenced him. Forming the [[John Mayer Trio]], he released the live album, ''[[Try!]]'' (2005) and his third studio album, ''[[Continuum (John Mayer album)|Continuum]]'' (2006). Both were met with positive critical reception, while the latter received a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]], and won both [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album|Best Pop Vocal Album]] and [[Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance|Best Male Pop Vocal Performance]] for its single, "[[Waiting on the World to Change]]" at the [[49th Annual Grammy Awards]]. It was followed by ''[[Battle Studies (album)|Battle Studies]]'' (2009) which marked his return to [[pop music|pop]].

After having several controversial incidents with the media, Mayer withdrew from public life in 2010 and drew inspiration from the 1970s pop music of [[Laurel Canyon, Los Angeles#History|Laurel Canyon]] for the sound of his fifth studio album, ''[[Born and Raised (John Mayer album)|Born and Raised]]'' (2012). Discovery of a [[granuloma]] on his vocal cords delayed the release of the album until May 2012, and forced him to cancel its accompanying tour. Despite favorable reception and becoming his second release to peak atop the ''Billboard'' 200, the album was less commercially successful than his previous work. Mayer recovered in January 2013 and released his sixth studio album, ''[[Paradise Valley (album)|Paradise Valley]]'' in August of that year, which peaked at number two on the chart and incorporated [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]], and [[Americana (music)|Americana]] influences. His seventh album, ''[[The Search for Everything]]'' (2017) was a loose [[concept album|concept]] based around themes of a romantic break-up. His eighth, ''[[Sob Rock]]'' (2021) was inspired by 1980s [[soft rock]] music.

In 2015, three former members of the [[Grateful Dead]] joined with Mayer and two other musicians to form the band [[Dead & Company]].<ref name=deadtour/> It was the latest of several [[Reunions of the Grateful Dead|reunions]] of the band's surviving members since [[Jerry Garcia]]'s death in 1995.<ref name= NYT-Launch16>{{Citation |date=February 8, 2016 |title=Dead & Company To Launch 2016 Tour |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |url=http://markets.on.nytimes.com/research/stocks/news/press_release.asp?docTag=201602080700PR_NEWS_USPRX____LA17152&feedID=600&press_symbol=3744685 |access-date=April 8, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420134946/http://markets.on.nytimes.com/research/stocks/news/press_release.asp?docTag=201602080700PR_NEWS_USPRX____LA17152&feedID=600&press_symbol=3744685 |archive-date=April 20, 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name= Nev11.27.A>{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=John |date=December 1, 2015 |title=Review + photos: Dead & Company a tale of two shows in one night at MGM Grand |website=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |url=http://lasvegassun.com/vegasdeluxe/2015/dec/01/review-photos-dead-company-a-tale-of-two-shows-one/ |access-date=April 8, 2016 |quote="With superb guitar skills and strong vocals on several titles ("West L.A. Fadeaway" and "Deal," among them), Mayer continued to win over the army of itinerant Deadheads in the audience Saturday night." |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406132255/http://lasvegassun.com/vegasdeluxe/2015/dec/01/review-photos-dead-company-a-tale-of-two-shows-one/ |archive-date= April 6, 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> Mayer's secondary career pursuits extend to television hosting, comedy, and writing; he has authored columns for magazines such as ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]''. He supports various causes and has performed at charity benefits. He is a watch aficionado (with a collection he values in the "tens of millions" of dollars), contributing to the watch site ''[[Hodinkee]]'', has been on the jury at the ''[[:fr:Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Genève|Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Genève]]'', and was appointed as the Creative Conduit of [[Audemars Piguet]] in 2024.<ref name=wrist>{{cite news| last= Williams| first= Alex |date= April 30, 2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/01/fashion/mens-style/john-mayer-watches.html |title= John Mayer's Wrist Is a Wonderland| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170323214242/https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/01/fashion/mens-style/john-mayer-watches.html |archive-date= March 23, 2017 |work= The New York Times| access-date= May 4, 2015}}</ref><ref name=":1" /> By 2014, he had sold a total of over 20 million albums worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://music.yahoo.com/photos/top-new-acts-since-2000-1403561474-slideshow/| title=USA: Top 20 New Acts Since 2000| website=Yahoo! Music| date= July 8, 2014| last=Grein| first=Paul| access-date=July 10, 2014| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714153307/https://music.yahoo.com/photos/top-new-acts-since-2000-1403561474-slideshow/| archive-date=July 14, 2014| url-status= live}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Kolgraf |first=Jackie |date=2023-11-27 |title=John Mayer Curates an Ever-Evolving World of Music on His Exclusive Channel |url=https://www.siriusxm.com/blog/life-with-john-mayer-channel |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=SiriusXM |language=en}}</ref>

==Early life==
Mayer was born on October 16, 1977, in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]].<ref name=allmusicbio /> His father, Richard Mayer (b. 1927), was principal at [[Central High School (Connecticut)|Central High School]] in Bridgeport, and his mother, Margaret (''née'' Hoffman; b. 1947), was a middle-school English teacher.<ref name="eliscu">{{cite magazine |last1=Eliscu |first1=Jenny |title=Songs in the Key of Mayer |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/songs-in-the-key-of-mayer-234694/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=April 15, 2020 |date=November 27, 2003}}</ref><ref name= hip>{{cite journal |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20138163,00.html |title= It's Hip to Be Square| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924150948/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20138163,00.html |archive-date= September 24, 2015| date= October 7, 2002| journal= [[People (magazine)|People]] | volume= 58| number= 15| page= 107}}</ref> He grew up in nearby [[Fairfield, Connecticut|Fairfield]], the middle child between older half-sister Rachel,<ref>{{cite AV media | people =Carl Mayer (@carlwmayer) | date =July 10, 2022 | title =$15 Game Show —John Mayers family instagram updates | medium =webshow | time =2m40s | location =White Plains, NY | publisher =Instagram }}</ref> older brother Carl, and younger brother Ben.<ref name=Brothers>{{cite web | last= Spillane |first= Sean |date= March 18, 2015|title=Central High School - John Mayer|url=http://bridgeport.ct.schoolwebpages.com/education/components/scrapbook/default.php?sectiondetailid=31898|website=School Web Pages |publisher=CT Post |access-date=February 13, 2004|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060321050346/http://bridgeport.ct.schoolwebpages.com/education/components/scrapbook/default.php?sectiondetailid=31898|archive-date=March 21, 2006|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=John Mayer|journal=[[TV Guide]] |url=https://tvguide.com/celebrities/john-mayer/bio/196620|access-date=August 25, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826115832/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/john-mayer/bio/196620|archive-date=August 26, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> His father is [[Jewish]], and Mayer has said that he "relates" to [[Judaism]].<ref name=Playboy/> As an elementary school student, Mayer became close friends with future tennis star [[James Blake (tennis)|James Blake]], and they played Nintendo together weekday afternoons after school for three years.<ref>{{cite journal| last= Tapper| first= Christina |date= August 23, 2008|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20220809,00.html | title= James Blake on John Mayer: No High School Lothario| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141018184225/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20220809,00.html |archive-date= October 18, 2014 |journal= People| access-date= March 23, 2015}}</ref> He attended the [[Center for Global Studies at Brien McMahon High School]] in [[Norwalk, Connecticut|Norwalk]] for his junior year (then known as the Center for Japanese Studies Abroad, a [[magnet school|magnet program]] for learning Japanese).<ref name= "eliscu" />

After watching [[Michael J. Fox]]'s guitar performance as [[Marty McFly]] in ''[[Back to the Future]]'', Mayer became fascinated with the instrument.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Duricka|first=Tamara|last8=!|date=July 3, 2015|title='Back to the Future' turns 30: Time sure does McFly|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/herocomplex/la-ca-hc-back-to-the-future-anniversary-20150708-story.html|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US}}</ref> When he turned 13 years old, his father rented one for him.<ref>{{cite web| year= 2005|url=https://www.pbs.org/wttw/soundstage/jmayer/bio.htm | work= Soundstage| title= John Mayer with special guest Buddy Guy| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512163150/http://www.pbs.org/wttw/soundstage/jmayer/bio.htm |archive-date= May 12, 2015 | via= [[PBS]].org| access-date= May 31, 2007}}</ref><ref name=AskMen>{{cite web| year= 2005|url=http://www.askmen.com/men/entertainment_100/140c_john_mayer.html | title= Men Of The Week: Entertainment—John Mayer| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118221108/http://www.askmen.com/men/entertainment_100/140c_john_mayer.html |archive-date= January 18, 2008 | website= AskMen.com| access-date= April 12, 2006}}</ref> A neighbor gave Mayer a [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] cassette, which cultivated Mayer's love of blues music.<ref name=CU>{{cite news| date= November 6, 2006|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/close-up/mon-nov-6-telecom-spam-attack-john-mayer-881586 | title= Mon Nov 6: Telecom; Spam Attack; John Mayer| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105044240/http://tvnz.co.nz/close-up/mon-nov-6-telecom-spam-attack-john-mayer-881586 |archive-date= January 5, 2016 | publisher= [[TVNZ]] | access-date= December 6, 2006}}</ref>{{cref|a}} According to Mayer, his fascination with Vaughan started a "genealogical hunt" that led him to other blues guitarists, including [[Buddy Guy]], [[B.B. King]], [[Freddie King]], [[Albert King]], [[Otis Rush]], and [[Lightnin' Hopkins]].<ref name=RSGG>{{cite magazine| author-link= David Fricke| first= David |last= Fricke|date= February 22, 2007|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/the-new-guitar-gods-20070222 |title= The New Guitar Gods| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018054537/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/the-new-guitar-gods-20070222 |archive-date= October 18, 2016 | magazine= Rolling Stone| number= 1020| pages= 39–47}}</ref> Mayer started taking lessons from a local guitar shop owner, Al Ferrante, and soon became consumed.<ref name=Hedegaard>{{cite magazine| last= Hedegaard| first= Erik |date= February 4, 2010| title= The Dirty Mind and Lonely Heart of John Mayer| magazine= Rolling Stone| number= 1097| pages= 36–45, 68}}</ref><ref name=Mather>{{cite web| last= Hedegaard| first= Erik |date= March 2008|url=http://www.menshealth.com/celebrity-fitness/article-print.php?102 | title= The Wonder of John Mayer Land| website= menshealth.com| publisher= Rodale| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402100704/http://www.menshealth.com/celebrity-fitness/article-print.php?102 | archive-date= April 2, 2015}}</ref> His singular focus concerned his parents, and they twice took him to see a psychiatrist, who determined him to be healthy.<ref name=Hedegaard/><ref name=Mather/> Mayer says that his parents' contentious marriage led him to "disappear and create my own world I could believe in".<ref name=Hedegaard/> After two years of practice, he started playing at bars and other venues, while still in high school.<ref name=AskMen /> In addition to performing solo, he was a member of a band called Villanova Junction (named for a [[Jimi Hendrix]] song) with Tim Procaccini, Joe Beleznay, and Rich Wolf.<ref name=Hedegaard/><ref name=TW>{{cite web| last= Wallace| first= William |date= January 1, 2005|url=http://www.tweedmag.com/News/Joe_Beleznay_wants_to_be_the_ball.html | title= Joe Beleznay wants to be the ball| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019032247/http://www.tweedmag.com/News/Joe_Beleznay_wants_to_be_the_ball.html |archive-date=October 19, 2006 |work= Tweed Magazine| access-date= October 30, 2006}}</ref>

When Mayer was 17, he was stricken with [[cardiac dysrhythmia]] and was hospitalized for a weekend. Reflecting on the incident, Mayer said, "That was the moment the songwriter in me was born", and he penned his first lyrics the night he left the hospital.<ref name=RS06>Hiatt, Brian (September 21, 2006), "My Big Mouth Strikes Again". ''Rolling Stone'' (1009): pp. 66–70.</ref> Shortly thereafter, he began suffering from [[panic attacks]], and says he feared having to enter a [[mental institution]].<ref name=Hedegaard/> He continues to manage such episodes with [[anti-anxiety drug|anti-anxiety medication]].<ref name=RS06/><ref name=MandS>{{cite web|url=http://a1135.g.akamai.net/f/1135/18227/1h/cchannel.download.akamai.com/18227/podcast/RICHMOND-VA/WRVQ-FM/johnmayer2.mp3 |title= John Mayer| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127141057/http://a1135.g.akamai.net/f/1135/18227/1h/cchannel.download.akamai.com/18227/podcast/RICHMOND-VA/WRVQ-FM/johnmayer2.mp3 | archive-date= January 27, 2012 | format= MP3 podcast |work= Melissa and Sid| date= March 31, 2008| publisher= [[WRVQ-FM]]}}</ref>

==Career==

===Early career (1996–1999)===
{{See also|Inside Wants Out}}
Mayer considered skipping college to pursue music, but his parents dissuaded him.<ref name=Hedegaard/> He enrolled at the [[Berklee College of Music]] in 1997 at age 19.<ref name=ELLE>Ruth Shaut (2006), "Blues Brother". ''Elle''. (250-251):104.</ref> At the urging of his college friend [[Clay Cook]], they left Berklee after two semesters and moved to Atlanta; there, they formed a two-man band called LoFi Masters, and began performing in local coffee houses and club venues such as [[Eddie's Attic]].<ref name=Berklee>{{cite web| last= Small| first= Mark |year=2005|url=http://www.berklee.edu/bt/172/coverstory.html |title= John Mayer '98: Running with the Big Dogs| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070410200154/http://www.berklee.edu/bt/172/coverstory.html |archive-date= April 10, 2007 |work= Berklee Today| via= Berklee.edu| publisher= Berklee College of Music| access-date= April 23, 2007}}</ref><ref name=AskMen/> According to Cook, they experienced musical differences due to Mayer's desire to move more towards pop music.<ref name=MOA>{{cite news| last= Guthrie| first= Blake |date= November 20, 2003|url=https://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/content-184733-Cover-Story--Mayer-of-Atlanta |title= Mayer of Atlanta: John Mayer plays Philips Arena, and all I got was this lousy cover story| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080110213456/http://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A14103 |archive-date= January 10, 2008 | work= [[Creative Loafing]]| access-date= February 17, 2007}}</ref> The two parted ways and Mayer embarked on a solo career.<ref name=Berklee/>

With the help of local producer and engineer Glenn Matullo, Mayer recorded the independent [[Extended play|EP]] ''[[Inside Wants Out]]''. The EP includes eight songs with Mayer on lead vocals and guitars. For the opening track, "Back To You", a full band was enlisted, including the EP's co-producer [[David LaBruyere|David "DeLa" LaBruyere]] on bass guitars.<ref name=MO>{{cite web| last= Alter| first= Gaby |date= April 1, 2007|url=http://mixonline.com/live/tourprofiles/audio_john_mayer_2/ |title= Tour Profile: John Mayer| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904114813/http://mixonline.com/live/tourprofiles/audio_john_mayer_2/ |archive-date=September 4, 2014 | work= Mix| via= mixonline.com| access-date= April 23, 2007}}</ref> Cook had co-written many of the album's songs, including its first commercial single release, "[[No Such Thing (John Mayer song)|No Such Thing]]"; however, his only performance contribution was backing vocals on the song "Comfortable".<ref name=MOA/>

===Major label and commercial success (2000–2004)===
{{See also|Room for Squares|Heavier Things}}

Mayer and LaBruyere performed throughout Georgia and nearby states.<ref name="Graham">{{cite web |last1=Graham |first1=George |title=George Graham Reviews John Mayer's 'Room for Squares' |url=http://georgegraham.com/reviews/jmayer.html |website=georgegraham.com |access-date=July 21, 2019 |date=April 10, 2002}}</ref> Also, as his career coincided with the then-nascent internet music market, Mayer benefited from an online following.<ref name=hay>Hay, Carla (April 6, 2002), "Aware/Columbia's John Mayer Makes 'Room For Squares' A Hit". ''Billboard''. '''114''' (14):22.</ref> Mayer came to the attention of [[Gregg Latterman]] at Aware Records through an acquaintance of Mayer's, a lawyer, who sent Aware his EP.<ref>{{cite news| last1= Wood| first1=Mikael|title=Room at the Top|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/room-at-the-top-6390314|access-date=December 22, 2017 |work= [[The Dallas Observer]] |date= March 28, 2002|quote=I met a great lawyer who was willing to promote me. He sent out my records to labels, and Aware was one of his first ideas. He knew my music well enough to know it was gonna take a smaller label to do it, and he was right. Aware was the label. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222162540/http://www.dallasobserver.com/music/room-at-the-top-6390314|archive-date=December 22, 2017| url-status= live}}</ref><ref name=Mather/><ref>{{cite web| last= Proefrock| first= Stacia |year= 2005 |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p405816|pure_url=yes}} |title= Biography| work= All Music Guide| access-date= April 23, 2007}}</ref> In early 2001, after including him in Aware Festival concerts and his songs on Aware compilations, Aware released Mayer's internet-only album, ''[[Room for Squares]]''. During this time, Aware concluded a deal with [[Columbia Records]] that gave Columbia first pick in signing Aware artists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.awarerecords.com/company.php |title= A Brief History| publisher= Aware Records| access-date= June 12, 2007| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070207084321/http://www.awarerecords.com/company.php |archive-date= February 7, 2007 }}</ref> In September, Columbia remixed and re-released ''Room for Squares''.<ref name=malindanewman>{{cite magazine| last= Newman| first= Melinda |date= September 8, 2001| title= The Beat| magazine= Billboard| volume= 113| number= 36| page= 14}}</ref> As part of the major label "debut", the album's artwork was updated, and the track "3x5" was added. The re-release included reworked studio versions of the first four songs from ''Inside Wants Out''.<ref>{{cite web| last= Back| first= Alan | date= June 15, 2001|url=http://www.nique.net/issues/2001-06-15/entertainment/2 |title= John Mayer carves out his own niche with national debut album| website= Nique.net | access-date= June 22, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929132049/http://www.nique.net/issues/2001-06-15/entertainment/2 |archive-date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref>

By the end of 2002, ''Room for Squares'' had spawned several radio hits, including "[[No Such Thing (John Mayer song)|No Such Thing]]", "[[Your Body Is a Wonderland]]", and "[[Why Georgia]]". It also received general praise critically, and Mayer drew comparisons to [[Dave Matthews]].<ref name= Berklee/><ref name=malindanewman/> In 2003, Mayer won a Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Best Male Pop Vocal Performance|Best Male Pop Vocal Performance]] for "Your Body Is a Wonderland".<ref name=Grammyverification>{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=%22john+mayer%22&field_nominee_work_value=&year=All&genre=All |title= Past Winners Search| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402133827/http://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=%22john+mayer%22&field_nominee_work_value=&year=All&genre=All |archive-date= April 2, 2015 |website= Grammy.com| access-date= March 18, 2015}}</ref> In his acceptance speech he remarked, "This is very, very fast, and I promise to catch up."<ref name=Mather/> He also figuratively referred to himself as being 16, a remark that many mistook to mean that he was 16 years old at the time.<ref name=RSG07>Serpick, Evan (February 2007), "Grammy Preview: John Mayer", ''Rolling Stone'', Volume unknown: p. 32.</ref>

In February 2003, Mayer released a live CD and DVD of a concert in [[Birmingham, Alabama]] titled ''[[Any Given Thursday]]'', which included songs previously not recorded, such as "Man on the Side", "[[Something's Missing (John Mayer song)|Something's Missing]]", and "Covered in Rain". Commercially, the album peaked at number 17 on the ''Billboard'' 200 chart.<ref name="Amazon - Any Given Thursday">{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Any-Given-Thursday-John-Mayer/dp/B000083GLC |title=John Mayer - Any Given Thursday - Amazon.com Music |access-date=July 28, 2019 |website=[[Amazon (company)|Amazon.com]] }}</ref> Its accompanying DVD release received conservative—although consistent—praise, with critics torn between his pop-idol image, and (at the time) emerging guitar prowess.<ref name=EW>Browne, David (March 14, 2003), [https://ew.com/article/2003/03/14/any-given-thursday/ "Strummer Time"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509233100/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,430023,00.html |date=May 9, 2012 }}. ''Entertainment Weekly''. (700):62.</ref> Erik Crawford of [[AllMusic]] asked, "Is [Mayer] the consummate guitar hero exemplified when he plays a cover of Stevie Ray Vaughan's '[[Lenny (instrumental)|Lenny]]', or is he the teen idol that the pubescent girls shriek for after he plays 'Your Body Is a Wonderland'?"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Crawford |first1=Erik |title=Review |url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r626637|pure_url=yes}} |date=June 8, 2007}}</ref><ref>Medsker, David (2003). [https://popmatters.com/music/reviews/m/mayerjohn-any.shtml "Love me, love me, say that you love me..."] Pop Matters. Retrieved June 8, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061112212945/http://www.popmatters.com/music/reviews/m/mayerjohn-any.shtml |date=November 12, 2006 }}</ref> That summer, Mayer went on the road with [[Counting Crows]] in a tour that spanned 42 dates between July 7 and September 2.<ref>Ault, Susanne (July 12, 2003), [https://books.google.com/books?id=5Q0EAAAAMBAJ&dq=Mayer%2C+Crows+Take+Their+Guitars+On+The+Road&pg=PA15 "Mayer, Crows Take Their Guitars On The Road"]. ''Billboard''. '''115''' (28):15.</ref>

''[[Heavier Things]]'', Mayer's second album, was released in 2003 to generally favorable reviews. ''Rolling Stone, Allmusic,'' and ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' all gave positive, although reserved, feedback.<ref>
MacNeil, Jason (2003).
[https://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/mayerjohn/heavierthings "Heavier Things"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514200644/http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/mayerjohn/heavierthings |date=May 14, 2007 }} Metacritic. Retrieved June 4, 2007.
</ref> The album was commercially successful, and while it did not sell as well as ''Room for Squares'', it peaked at number one on the US ''Billboard'' 200 chart. The song "[[Daughters (John Mayer song)|Daughters]]" won the 2005 Grammy for [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]],<ref name=Grammyverification/> and reached #1 on the ''Billboard'' Adult Pop Songs chart<ref>[https://www.billboard.com/artist/304974/john-mayer/chart?page=1&f=343 "John Mayer Chart History – Adult Pop Songs] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160612232828/http://www.billboard.com/artist/304974/john-mayer/chart?page=1&f=343 |date=June 12, 2016 }}, retrieved February 28, 2016.</ref> and #19 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref>[https://www.billboard.com/artist/304974/john-mayer/chart?page=1&f=379 "John Mayer Chart History – Hot 100] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160613054001/http://www.billboard.com/artist/304974/john-mayer/chart?page=1&f=379 |date=June 13, 2016 }}, retrieved February 28, 2016.</ref> He dedicated the award to his grandmother, Annie Hoffman, who had died in May 2004.<ref>(May 21–22, 2004), [http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/ctpost/obituary.aspx?n=annie-j-hoffman&pid=2250825 "Annie J. Hoffman-Obituary"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/ctpost/obituary.aspx?n=annie-j-hoffman&pid=2250825 |date=October 17, 2015 }}. Legacy.com. Retrieved August 2, 2015.</ref> He also won Best Male Pop Vocal Performance. On February 9, 2009, Mayer told [[Ellen DeGeneres]] that he thought he should not have won the Grammy for Song of the year because he thought that Alicia Keys' "[[If I Ain't Got You]]" was the better song. Because of this, he removed the top half of the Grammy and gave it to Keys, and kept the bottom part for himself. At the 37th Annual [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] Induction Ceremony in 2006, Mayer received the [[Hal David Starlight Award]].<ref>(2006) [http://www.songwritershalloffame.org/award_recipient_detail.asp?ceremonyId=27&awardRecipientId=150 John Mayer]. Song Writers Hall of Fame. Retrieved September 29, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001163422/http://www.songwritershalloffame.org/award_recipient_detail.asp?ceremonyId=27&awardRecipientId=150 |date=October 1, 2006 }}</ref>

Mayer again recorded live concerts across seven nights of his U.S. tour in 2004. These recordings were released to the [[iTunes Store]] under the title ''[[As/Is]]'', indicating that the errors were included along with the good moments. A few months later, a "best of" CD was compiled from the ''As/Is'' nights. The album included a previously unreleased cover of [[Marvin Gaye]]'s song "[[Inner City Blues (Make Me Wanna Holler)]]", featuring a solo from Mayer's supporting act—jazz and blues turntablist [[DJ Logic]]. The album covers of the ''As/Is'' releases feature drawings of [[anthropomorphic]] bunnies.<ref>[http://www.johnmayer.com/bio Bio] JohnMayer.com. Retrieved June 25, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070720121613/http://www.johnmayer.com/bio |date=July 20, 2007 }}</ref>

===Change in musical direction (2005–2008)===
{{See also|John Mayer Trio|Continuum (John Mayer album)}}
As early as 2002, Chris Willman with ''Entertainment Weekly'' said that Mayer was "more historically savvy, and more ambitious than you'd guess from the unforced earnestness of ''[Room for] Squares''{{-"}}.<ref name=willman>Willman, Chris (August 9, 2002), "Meet John Dough". ''Entertainment Weekly''. (666):36.</ref> However, Mayer was largely associated with the Adult Contemporary and singer-songwriter genres.<ref name=willman/> Fame allowed him access to his early influences, and he began collaborating with blues and jazz artists. He accompanied Buddy Guy in a concert at the Irving Plaza in December 2003.<ref>Fricke, David (February 5, 2004), "Buddy Guy/John Mayer". ''Rolling Stone''. (941):68.</ref> He toured with jazz pianist [[Herbie Hancock]], including a show at the [[Bonnaroo Music Festival]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/61680/herbie-hancock-goes-beyond-jazz|title=Herbie Hancock Goes Beyond Jazz|date=August 24, 2005|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=December 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181217105657/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/61680/herbie-hancock-goes-beyond-jazz|archive-date=December 17, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> He also performed on commercial releases, namely, with [[Eric Clapton]] (''[[Back Home (Eric Clapton album)|Back Home]]'', [[Crossroads Guitar Festival]]), [[Buddy Guy]] (''[[Bring 'Em In (Buddy Guy album)|Bring 'Em In]])'', [[John Scofield]] (''[[That's What I Say (John Scofield album)|That's What I Say]]''), and [[B.B. King]] (''[[B. B. King & Friends: 80|80]]''). Although Mayer maintained his reputation as a singer-songwriter, he gained distinction as a guitarist.

Following the conclusion of his ''Heavier Things'' tour, Mayer began working with artists, including those from other genres of music. His voice was sampled on the song "[[Be (Common album)#"Go!"|Go]]" by rapper [[Common (rapper)|Common]], and he appeared on a hidden track called "Bittersweet Poetry" from the [[Kanye West]] album ''[[Graduation (album)|Graduation]]''.{{cref|b}} The collaborations drew praise from rap heavyweights [[Jay-Z]] and [[Nelly]].<ref>Rodriguez, Jason (April 13, 2007). [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1557129/20070413/id_0.jhtml "Shawty's Story: Lloyd Says He Stole From Usher, Loves John Mayer"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070429045605/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1557129/20070413/id_0.jhtml |date=April 29, 2007 }} MTV. Retrieved April 16, 2007.</ref> When asked about his presence in the [[hip hop]] community, Mayer said, "It's not music out there right now. That's why, to me, hip-hop is where rock used to be."<ref name=trio>Moss, Corey (January 5, 2005) [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1495325/01052005/mayer_john.jhtml "John Mayer Plans To 'Close Up Shop On Acoustic Sensitive'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050222090731/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1495325/01052005/mayer_john.jhtml |date=February 22, 2005 }}. MTV. Retrieved April 12, 2006.</ref>

Around this time Mayer announced that he was "closing up shop on acoustic sensitivity".<ref name=trio/> In the spring of 2005, Mayer formed the John Mayer Trio with bassist [[Pino Palladino]] and drummer [[Steve Jordan (musician)|Steve Jordan]], both of whom he had met through studio sessions. The trio combined blues and rock music. In October 2005, they opened for [[the Rolling Stones]]<ref>Moss Corey (September 16, 2005). [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1509723/20050916/mayer_john.jhtml "John Mayer Trio Geek Out With Live Album, Rolling Stones Jokes"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071001032146/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1509723/20050916/mayer_john.jhtml |date=October 1, 2007 }}. MTV. Retrieved June 8, 2007.</ref> and that November released a live album called ''[[Try!]]'' The band took a break in mid-2006.{{Clear}}

[[File:John Mayer live in 2007 01.png|thumb|left|Mayer performing in San Jose, California, June 2007]]
Mayer's third studio album, titled ''[[Continuum (John Mayer album)|Continuum]]'', was released on September 12, 2006, produced by Mayer and [[Steve Jordan (musician)|Steve Jordan]]. Mayer suggested the album was intended to combine blues and pop. In that vein, two of the tracks from his Trio release ''Try!''—"Vultures" and "Gravity"—were included on ''Continuum''.<ref name=ELLE/> Despite his excitement, in a ''Rolling Stone'' interview, Mayer recalled that after former Columbia Records head [[Don Ienner]] panned ''Continuum'' he briefly considered quitting music and studying design full-time.<ref name=RS06/>

In May 2006, Mayer contributed a cover of the song "[[(Get Your Kicks on) Route 66#Other recorded renditions|Route 66]]" for the [[Pixar]] animated film ''[[Cars (film)|Cars]]'' (2006). Mayer's rendition garnered a 
nomination at the [[49th Grammy Awards]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Solo Rock Vocal Performance|Best Solo Rock Vocal Performance]].

The first single from ''Continuum'' was "[[Waiting on the World to Change]]", which debuted on ''[[The Ron and Fez Show]]''. The song was the third-most downloaded song of the week on the [[iTunes Store]] following its release on July 11, 2006,{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} and debuted at number 25 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] Chart.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} On August 23, 2006, Mayer debuted the entire album on the Los Angeles radio station [[KYSR|Star 98.7]], offering commentary on each track.<ref>Mayer, John (2006). [http://johnmayer.com/blog/john/200608#83 "Continuum First Listen"] JohnMayer.com. Retrieved June 8, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141126220122/http://johnmayer.com/blog/john/200608#83 |date=November 26, 2014 }}</ref> A subsequent version was released the next day on the [[Clear Channel Communications|Clear Channel Music]] website as a streaming sneak preview. On September 21, 2006, Mayer appeared on ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'' in the episode "Built to Kill, Part 1", playing "Waiting on the World to Change" and "Slow Dancing in a Burning Room". The song "Gravity" was featured on the television series ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'', in the episode "Cane & Able" and ''[[Numb3rs]]''. He recorded a session for the British program ''[[Live from Abbey Road]]'' at [[Abbey Road Studios]] on October 22, 2006.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}

On December 7, 2006, Mayer was nominated for five Grammy Awards, including [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=Variety Staff|date=December 7, 2006|title=Grammy nominations list (part 1)|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/awards/grammy-nominations-list-part-1-1117955271/|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=Variety|language=en-US}}</ref> The Trio received a nomination for ''Try!''. He won two: Best Pop Song with Vocal for "Waiting on the World to Change" and [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Album|Best Pop Album]] for ''Continuum''.<ref name=Grammyverification/> Mayer remixed an acoustic version of his single "Waiting on the World to Change" with vocal additions from fellow musician [[Ben Harper]]. In preparation for ''Continuum'', Mayer had booked the [[Village Recorder]] in Los Angeles to record five acoustic versions of his songs with veteran musician [[Robbie McIntosh]]. These recordings became ''[[The Village Sessions]]'', an EP released on December 12, 2006. As usual, Mayer oversaw the artwork.<ref>[http://www.johnmayer.com/news/archive/200612 "'The Village Sessions' Released Today"]. JohnMayer.com. Retrieved June 8, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110104217/http://www.johnmayer.com/news/archive/200612 |date=November 10, 2014 }}</ref> The initial North American ''Continuum'' tour ended on February 28, 2007, with a show at [[Madison Square Garden]].{{citation needed|date=August 2023}}

On November 20, 2007, the re-issue of ''Continuum'' became available online and in stores. The release contained a bonus disc of six live songs from his 2007 tour: five from ''Continuum'' and a cover of the [[Ray Charles]] song "[[I Don't Need No Doctor]]".<ref>JohnMayer.org staff [http://www.johnmayer.com/news/archive/200711#2 "Continuum (special edition) to be released on November 20; includes 6 live tracks and new single, ''Say''"]. Retrieved November 19, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150120234840/http://www.johnmayer.com/news/archive/200711#2 |date=January 20, 2015 }}</ref> His single "[[Say (John Mayer song)|Say]]", from the film ''The'' ''Bucket List,'' became available through [[iTunes]].{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} On December 6, 2007, "Belief" was nominated for Best Male Pop Vocal for the [[50th Annual Grammy Awards]]. He accompanied [[Alicia Keys]] on guitar on her song "[[No One (Alicia Keys song)|No One]]" at the ceremony.<ref>[[Josh Tyrangiel|Tyrangiel, Josh]] {{cite journal|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1710840_1710850_1710881,00.html|title=Alicia Keys with John Mayer - The 50th Annual Grammy Awards|date=February 8, 2008|journal=[[Time Magazine|Time]]|access-date=December 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190414103058/http://content.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1710840_1710850_1710881,00.html|archive-date=April 14, 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Additionally, he was selected by the editors of ''Time'' magazine as one of the [[Time 100|100 Most Influential People of 2007]], listed among artists and entertainers.<ref name=time100>[[Tyrangiel, Josh]] (May 14, 2007) [http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/time100/article/0,28804,1595326_1595332_1616690,00.html "John Mayer"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505052717/http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/time100/article/0,28804,1595326_1595332_1616690,00.html |date=May 5, 2007 }} ''Time'' '''169''' (20): p. 140.</ref>

In February 2008, Mayer hosted a three-day Caribbean cruise event that included performances with various musicians including [[David Ryan Harris]], [[Brett Dennen]], [[Colbie Caillat]], and [[Dave Barnes]], among others. The event was called "The Mayercraft Carrier" and was held aboard the cruise ship known as the ''[[Carnival Victory]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mayercraftcarrier.com/artists.html|website=MayercraftCarrier.com|access-date=September 26, 2007|title=Mayercraft Carrier Cruise: February 1–4, 2008: A John Mayer/Sixthman Experience|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011001821/http://mayercraftcarrier.com/artists.html|archive-date=October 11, 2007|url-status=dead}}</ref> A follow-up cruise titled "Mayercraft Carrier 2" sailed from Los Angeles March 27–31, 2009, on the [[Carnival Splendor]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=John Mayer Talks Oscars, 'Mayercraft Carrier 2' & Britney Spears|url=https://www.nbcwashington.com/local/john_mayer_talks_oscars___mayercraft_carrier_2____britney_spears/1866311/|access-date=February 2, 2021|website=NBC4 Washington|date=February 26, 2009 |language=en-US}}</ref>

On July 1, 2008, Mayer released ''[[Where the Light Is: John Mayer Live in Los Angeles|Where the Light Is]]'', a live concert film of Mayer's performance at the Nokia Theatre [[L.A. Live]] on December 8, 2007.<ref name="RS where the light is">{{cite magazine|last=Kemp|first=Mark|title=Where The Light Is: John Mayer Live In Los Angeles - Albums Reviews|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/where-the-light-is-john-mayer-live-in-los-angeles-20080701|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=December 23, 2013|date=July 1, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324035227/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/where-the-light-is-john-mayer-live-in-los-angeles-20080701|archive-date=March 24, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> The film was directed by [[Danny Clinch]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmayer.com/blog#1952|title=DVD Shoot|author=Mayer, John |website=JohnMayer.com |date=November 26, 2007 |access-date=December 29, 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229095313/http://www.johnmayer.com/blog#1952|archive-date=December 29, 2007|url-status=dead}}</ref> It features Mayer opening with an acoustic set, followed by a blues set with the Trio and concluded by a full set with the band from the ''Continuum'' album.<ref name="billboard blackberry">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1045927/mayer-aligns-with-blackberry-for-summer-tour|title=Mayer Aligns With Blackberry For Summer Tour|author=Waddell, Ray|magazine=Billboard|date=April 7, 2008|access-date=April 8, 2008| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506181919/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1045927/mayer-aligns-with-blackberry-for-summer-tour| archive-date= May 6, 2008 | url-status=live}}</ref>

===''Battle Studies'' (2009)===
{{main|Battle Studies (album)}}
Australian artist [[Guy Sebastian]] invited Mayer to collaborate on three songs from his 2009 album ''[[Like It Like That (album)|Like It Like That]]''.<ref>Cashmere, Paul (August 3, 2009), [http://www.undercover.com.au/News-Story.aspx?id=8910 "Guy Sebastian Album To Be Released In October"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016133045/http://www.undercover.com.au/News-Story.aspx?id=8910 |date=October 16, 2009 }}. ''Undercover Music News''. Retrieved August 4, 2009.</ref> Mayer also played guitar on the title track of [[Crosby Loggins]]' debut LP, ''Time to Move''.<ref>Newman-Bremang, Kathleen (May 12, 2009), [http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1611223/20090512/mraz_jason.jhtml "Crosby Loggins Nabs John Mayer, Kara DioGuardi For Debut Album'Rock the Cradle' winner plans to drop Time to Move in July"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515132254/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1611223/20090512/mraz_jason.jhtml |date=May 15, 2009 }}. MTV. Retrieved June 24, 2009.</ref>

On July 7, 2009, Mayer performed an instrumental guitar version of [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[Human Nature (Michael Jackson song)|Human Nature]]" at Jackson's televised [[Michael Jackson memorial service|memorial service]].<ref>Powers, Ann; Martens, Todd (July 7, 2009), [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/07/michael-jackson-memorial-john-mayer-performs-human-nature.html "Michael Jackson memorial: John Mayer performs 'Human Nature'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170204035742/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/07/michael-jackson-memorial-john-mayer-performs-human-nature.html |date=February 4, 2017 }}. ''Los Angeles Times'' blog. Retrieved July 8, 2009.</ref> He co-wrote "World of Chances" with [[Demi Lovato]] for Lovato's second album ''[[Here We Go Again (Demi Lovato album)|Here We Go Again]]'', released later that month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1616552/demi-lovato-gets-personal-on-here-we-go-again.jhtml|title=Demi Lovato Gets Personal on Here We Go Again|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|date=July 21, 2009|website=MTV News|access-date=April 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216012158/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1616552/demi-lovato-gets-personal-on-here-we-go-again.jhtml|archive-date=February 16, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref>

After the overwhelming success of ''Continuum'', Mayer confessed to be intimidated with beginning on a follow-up. However, he stated, "I think it got a lot easier when I realized that no matter what I do, it's not going to be ''Continuum'', good or bad."<ref name=micktaylor/> On November 17, 2009, Mayer's fourth studio album, ''[[Battle Studies (album)|Battle Studies]]'', debuted at number one on the U.S. [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart.<ref>SISARIO, BEN (November 26, 2009), "John Mayer Is No. 1 in Pre-Holiday Week". ''The New York Times''. :2.</ref> The first single, "[[Who Says (John Mayer song)|Who Says]]", was released on September 24, 2009, in advance of the album, followed on October 19 by "[[Heartbreak Warfare]]" and "[[Half of My Heart]]" on June 21, 2010. The accompanying arena tour grossed {{USD}}45 million.<ref name=DIEHL/> Despite the album's commercial success, critics reactions were mixed. Some reviews glowed, calling it his "most adventurous",<ref>Graff, Gary (November 14, 2009), "Battle Studies". ''Billboard''. '''121''' (45):32.</ref><ref>Arnold, Chuck (November 30, 2009), "Battle Studies". ''People''.'''72''' (22): p. 49.</ref> others called the album "safe" and noted that "Mayer the singer-songwriter and Mayer the man about town sometimes seem disconnected, like they don't even belong in the same body".<ref name=Hedegaard/><ref>Jerry Shriver; Elysa Gardner; [[Edna Gundersen]] (November 17, 2009), "Albums". ''USA Today''.</ref><ref>Greenblatt, Leah (November 20, 2009), "Battle Studies".'' Entertainment Weekly''. (1076):84.</ref><ref>Keefe, Jonathan (November 22, 2009), [https://slantmagazine.com/music/review/john-mayer-battle-studies/1918 "John Mayer – Battle Studies"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205082449/http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/john-mayer-battle-studies/1918 |date=February 5, 2010 }}. ''Slant''. Retrieved February 8, 2010.</ref> Mayer admitted to ''Rolling Stone'' that he thought ''Battle Studies'' was not his best album.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayers-dirty-mind-lonely-heart-new-issue-of-rolling-stone-20100119|title=John Mayer's Dirty Mind Lonely Heart|magazine=Rolling Stone|date=January 19, 2010|access-date=July 24, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713014502/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayers-dirty-mind-lonely-heart-new-issue-of-rolling-stone-20100119|archive-date=July 13, 2011|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pinkisthenewblog.com/2010/01/john-mayer-does-rolling-stone-magazine|title=John Mayer Does 'Rolling Stone' Magazine|website=Pink is the New Blog|date=January 20, 2010|access-date=July 24, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715085059/http://www.pinkisthenewblog.com/2010/01/john-mayer-does-rolling-stone-magazine/|archive-date=July 15, 2011|url-status=live}}</ref>

===Personal troubles and hiatus (2010–2013)===
{{see also|Born and Raised (John Mayer album)}}

{{quote box|width=350px|align=right|quote=I did a lot of therapy, like anti-acid reflux, and it didn't work, then I went on vocal rest. No alcohol. No spicy food. No talking. Most of September I wasn't talking at all. I'd have a Bluetooth keyboard, and someone would have an iPad to read what I type. I had to point to menus at restaurants.|source=John Mayer<ref name="mayer silent">{{cite web|title=John Mayer: 'I was silent for a month' |url=http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2012/06/11/john-mayer-%E2%80%98i-was-silent-for-a-month%E2%80%99/|website=San Francisco Chronicle| date=June 11, 2012| access-date=June 12, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612201357/http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2012/06/11/john-mayer-%e2%80%98i-was-silent-for-a-month%e2%80%99/|archive-date=June 12, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>}} Following two revealing and highly controversial magazine interviews in February 2010 with ''Rolling Stone'' and ''Playboy'' magazines,<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Herrera |first=Monica |date=2010-02-10 |title=John Mayer's Sexually, Racially Charged Playboy Interview Sparks Outrage |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/john-mayers-sexually-racially-charged-playboy-interview-sparks-outrage-959433/ |access-date=2023-09-08 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> Mayer withdrew from public life and ceased giving interviews. While still on tour for ''Battle Studies'', he began work in earnest on his fifth studio album—which drew on the popular music of [[Laurel Canyon, Los Angeles#History|Laurel Canyon]] in the early 1970s.<ref name=sniping>Wood, Mikael (August 15, 2013), [https://latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-mn-mayer-swift-personal-20130818-story.html#page=1 "Musical sniping, a la John Mayer and Taylor Swift"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411165722/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-mn-mayer-swift-personal-20130818-story.html#page=1 |date=April 11, 2015 }}. ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved March 25, 2015.</ref> Around this time, he began to experience vocal problems, and sought medical assistance.<ref name=DIEHL>{{cite magazine| last= Diehl| first= Matt | date= March 30, 2013|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1554215/john-mayer-the-billboard-cover-story |title= Breaking the Silence| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150409093418/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1554215/john-mayer-the-billboard-cover-story |archive-date= April 9, 2015 | magazine= Billboard| volume= 125| number= 12| pages= 30–35}}</ref> On September 16, 2011, he posted on his blog that his next record, ''Born and Raised,'' would be delayed due to treatment he was receiving for a [[granuloma]] discovered on his vocal cords.<ref>{{cite magazine |author=Matthew Perpetua |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-diagnosed-with-throat-condition-20110919 |title=John Mayer Diagnosed With Throat Condition |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=September 19, 2011 |access-date=April 16, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120429102422/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-diagnosed-with-throat-condition-20110919 |archive-date= April 29, 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> Mayer described the event as a "temporary setback" and added that the album was entirely finished except for a few vocal tracks.<ref>Levy, Daniel S. (October 3, 2011), "Passages".''People''. '''76''' (13):76.</ref> A month later, on October 20, 2011, Mayer posted, "I had surgery this afternoon to remove it and am now on complete vocal rest for a month or more," during which he planned to "travel the country, look, and listen".<ref>Fowler, Brandi (October 23, 2011), [http://www.eonline.com/news/271064/john-mayer-has-surgery-to-heal-vocal-cords "John Mayer Has Surgery to Heal Vocal Cords"] {{Webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403171340/http://www.eonline.com/news/271064/john-mayer-has-surgery-to-heal-vocal-cords |date=April 3, 2015 }}. ''E!''. Retrieved March 23, 2015.</ref> However, the surgery did not work as expected, and he had to undergo another one that August.<ref name= "mayer silent" /><ref name=patrickdoyle>Doyle, Patrick (January 30, 2013), [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-john-mayer-on-his-new-voice-summer-tour-and-dating-katy-perry-20130130#ixzz3UqmCmNvs Q&A: John Mayer on His New Voice, Summer Tour and Dating Katy Perry] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170903121602/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/q-a-john-mayer-on-his-new-voice-summer-tour-and-dating-katy-perry-20130130#ixzz3UqmCmNvs |date=September 3, 2017 }}. ''Rolling Stone''. Retrieved March 19, 2015.</ref> During his travels, he visited and fell in love with [[Bozeman, Montana]], where he bought a house and re-settled in the spring of 2012.<ref name="ellen" /><ref name="Missoula Independent">Browning, Skylar (May 15, 2012), [http://missoulanews.bigskypress.com/IndyBlog/archives/2012/05/15/john-mayer-now-lives-in-montana "John Mayer now lives in Montana"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927065526/http://missoulanews.bigskypress.com/IndyBlog/archives/2012/05/15/john-mayer-now-lives-in-montana |date=September 27, 2012 }}. ''Missoula Independent''. Retrieved June 1, 2012.</ref><ref name="CBS Sunday morning">{{cite web|title=John Mayer: His "Shadow Days" Are Over"|date=February 10, 2013 |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/john-mayer-his-shadow-days-are-over/|publisher=CBS news|access-date=February 10, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131218183037/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/john-mayer-his-shadow-days-are-over/|archive-date=December 18, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref>

[[File:The Rolling Stones with John Mayer, Prudential Center 2012-12-13.jpg|thumb|left|240px|Mayer on stage with [[The Rolling Stones]] at the [[Prudential Center]], New Jersey, December 13, 2012]]
With his treatments complete, Mayer finished the vocals on ''Born and Raised'',<ref name=DIEHL/> and the album's first single, "Shadow Days", was released on February 27, 2012. The following day, he released the track listing for the album, announcing that it would be released on May 22 of that year.<ref name="born and raised track listing">{{cite web|url=http://johnmayer.com/news/news-18431927036/ |title=News |website=John Mayer |access-date=April 16, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120503033911/http://johnmayer.com/news/news-18431927036/ |archive-date=May 3, 2012 }}</ref> He described it as his "most honest" album,<ref name="ellen" /> and begin booking dates at more "intimate" venues than for ''Battle Studies''.<ref name=DIEHL/> He also accepted an invitation to appear at the [[South by Southwest]] festival.<ref name=DIEHL/> However, the granuloma returned, and on March 9, 2012, Mayer announced that he had been forced to cancel his tour and refrain from all singing indefinitely.<ref>Oldenburg, Ann (March 9, 2012), [http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2012/03/john-mayer-cancels-tour-takes-indefinite-hiatus/1 "John Mayer cancels tour, takes 'indefinite hiatus'"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310125955/http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2012/03/john-mayer-cancels-tour-takes-indefinite-hiatus/1 |date=March 10, 2012 }}. ''USA TODAY''. Retrieved March 18, 2015.</ref> Even so, ''Born and Raised'' was released as scheduled, and entered the ''Billboard'' 200 chart at number one, selling 219,000 copies in its first week.<ref name=DIEHL/> It also received generally positive critical feedback; ''Rolling Stone'' rated it number 17 on its list of the 50 Best Albums of 2012,<ref>{{cite magazine|last=''Rolling Stone'' staff|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-albums-of-2012-20121205/john-mayer-born-and-raised-19691231|title=John Mayer, 'Born and Raised' |date=December 5, 2012|access-date=March 25, 2015|magazine=Rolling Stone|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150331060151/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/50-best-albums-of-2012-20121205/john-mayer-born-and-raised-19691231 |archive-date=March 31, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> and ''People'' magazine called it "a shimmering album".<ref>Arnold, Chuck (May 28, 2012), [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20596474,00.html "John Mayer's "Born and Raised" Is a Perfect Road Trip Album: Review"] {{Webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402161554/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20596474,00.html |date=April 2, 2015 }}, ''People''. '''77''' (22):47.</ref> Meanwhile, Mayer brought a new focus to his guitar playing and, fearing that his vocal cords had been permanently damaged, tried to come to terms with a possible future as a [[session musician]].<ref name=DIEHL/> Determined to be cured, he sought help from the [[UCLA]] Voice Center.<ref name=DIEHL/> That September, [[otolaryngologist]] Dr. Gerald Berke paralyzed Mayer's vocal cords with a series of high-dose [[Botox#Medical uses|Botox]] injections, hoping that they would allow the granuloma to heal.<ref name=DIEHL/> Mayer's vocal rest extended to several months and,<ref>{{cite web|last=Oldenburg|first=Ann|title=After more throat surgery, John Mayer takes vow of silence |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2012/09/after-more-throat-surgery-john-mayer-takes-vow-of-silence/1|website=USA Today| access-date=February 18, 2013|date=September 4, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214121203/http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2012/09/after-more-throat-surgery-john-mayer-takes-vow-of-silence/1|archive-date=February 14, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> unable to even talk, his performances were limited to accompanying other artists on guitar. He appeared in September 2012 on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', where he joined musical guest [[Frank Ocean]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Markman|first=Rob|title=Frank Ocean's Big Weekend: 'SNL' Debut And A Brand-New Video|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1693922/frank-ocean-snl-pyramids-single.jhtml |website=MTV.com |access-date=February 18, 2013|date=September 17, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121123134756/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1693922/frank-ocean-snl-pyramids-single.jhtml|archive-date=November 23, 2012 |url-status=dead}}</ref> He played with the [[Rolling Stones]] in New Jersey in December 2012.<ref name=DIEHL/>

By January 2013, Mayer had recovered sufficiently enough to perform at a benefit concert in Bozeman, after almost two years without singing publicly.<ref name="benefitconcert">{{cite web|last=Hergett|first=Rachel|title=Welcome home|url=http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/article_263a856c-606e-11e2-9626-001a4bcf887a.html|website=The Bozeman Daily Chronicle |access-date=February 18, 2013 |date=January 16, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120143224/http://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/article_263a856c-606e-11e2-9626-001a4bcf887a.html|archive-date=January 20, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> In April 2013, he made an appearance at the [[Crossroads Guitar Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Harp|first=Justin|title=John Mayer, Jeff Beck join Eric Clapton's Crossroads festival |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a441917/john-mayer-jeff-beck-join-eric-claptons-crossroads-festival.html|website=[[Digital Spy]] |access-date= February 18, 2013|date=November 29, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214065833/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a441917/john-mayer-jeff-beck-join-eric-claptons-crossroads-festival.html |archive-date=February 14, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> and at the 28th Annual [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] Induction Ceremony, where he inducted the late [[Albert King]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Graff|first=Gary|title=Foo Fighters, Don Henley, John Mayer Lead 2013 Rock Hall Presenters|url=https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/record-labels/1521511/foo-fighters-don-henley-john-mayer-lead-2013-rock-hall| magazine= Billboard |access-date=February 18, 2013|date=January 23, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130204072239/http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/record-labels/1521511/foo-fighters-don-henley-john-mayer-lead-2013-rock-hall|archive-date=February 4, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> A show at the [[Tuscaloosa Amphitheater]] in Alabama on April 25, 2013, followed by a set at the [[New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival]] the next day, marked his first full-length concerts since his health troubles.<ref name= DIEHL/><ref>{{cite web|last=Barton|first=Chris|title=Fleetwood Mac and Frank Ocean lead New Orleans Jazz Fest lineup |url=https://latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-frank-ocean-wayne-shorter-new-orleans-jazz-fest-20130117,0,6757985.story|website=Los Angeles Times| access-date=February 18, 31, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>Hughes Cobb, Mark (April 26, 2013), [http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20130426/news/130429796 "John Mayer starts off season at Tuscaloosa Amphitheater"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402222743/http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20130426/news/130429796 |date=April 2, 2015 }}, ''Tuscaloosa News''. Retrieved March 20, 2015.</ref>

===''Paradise Valley'', Dead & Company, ''The Search for Everything'' (2013–2018)===
{{main|Paradise Valley (album)|Dead & Company|The Search for Everything}}
[[File:John Mayer at the Barclays Center.jpeg|thumbnail|Mayer performing at the [[Barclays Center]] in [[Brooklyn, New York]], on December 17, 2013]]
In June 2013, Mayer announced that he was finishing work on his sixth album, ''[[Paradise Valley (album)|Paradise Valley]].''<ref>{{cite web|date=June 18, 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151686223176252&set=a.157882861251.115273.5295171251&type=1|title=It's official. the new album is Paradise Valley|website=Facebook|access-date=June 18, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151686223176252&set=a.157882861251.115273.5295171251&type=1|archive-date=October 17, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> Produced by [[Don Was]], the album features "low-key folk-rock tunes".<ref name=sniping/><ref name=VOZICK>VOZICK-LEVINSON, SIMON (September 12, 2013), [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-swears-hes-done-with-the-fame-game-20130830 "John Mayer Swears He's Done With the Fame Game] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827130254/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-swears-hes-done-with-the-fame-game-20130830 |date=August 27, 2017 }}". ''Rolling Stone''. (1191):16.</ref> He collaborated with [[Frank Ocean]] on the song "Wildfire Pt. 2",<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Coulehan|first=Eric|title=New John Mayer Album Features Katy Perry, Frank Ocean|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/new-john-mayer-album-features-katy-perry-frank-ocean-20130808|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=December 24, 2013|date=August 8, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020122507/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/new-john-mayer-album-features-katy-perry-frank-ocean-20130808|archive-date=October 20, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> and with [[Katy Perry]] on "[[Who You Love]]".<ref name=ParadiseNow>{{cite magazine|last=Danton|first=Eric R.|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/listen-to-john-mayers-paradise-valley-now-20130813|title=Listen to John Mayer's 'Paradise Valley' Now|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=August 13, 2013|date=August 13, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130816040801/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/listen-to-john-mayers-paradise-valley-now-20130813|archive-date=August 16, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> The latter song would go on to become the album's third single, and an accompanying music video was released on December 17.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Miller|first=Julie|title=Exclusive: John Mayer and Katy Perry's First Portraits Together, Commemorating Their 'Who You Love' Single|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/12/john-mayer-katy-perry-who-you-love-artwork_slideshow_item4_5|magazine=Vanity Fair|date=December 2, 2013|access-date=December 3, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131205010559/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/12/john-mayer-katy-perry-who-you-love-artwork_slideshow_item4_5|archive-date=December 5, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> On June 18, 2013, he released a lyric video for the album's first single, "Paper Doll", on his official YouTube page.<ref>{{cite AV media | date = June 18, 2013 | title = John Mayer – Paper Doll (Lyric) | medium = Music video |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=565tXd1UyYI | access-date = March 19, 2015 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317083308/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=565tXd1UyYI | archive-date = March 17, 2015 | url-status=live }}</ref> The album was released August 20, 2013,<ref>Danton, Eric R (August 13, 2013), [https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/listen-to-john-mayers-paradise-valley-now-20130813#ixzz3VEHiZNYd "Listen to John Mayer's 'Paradise Valley' Now"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130816040801/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/listen-to-john-mayers-paradise-valley-now-20130813#ixzz3VEHiZNYd |date=August 16, 2013 }}. Retrieved March 23, 2015.</ref> and—meeting with positive reviews<ref name=metacritic>{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/paradise-valley/john-mayer/critic-reviews |title=Critic Reviews for Paradise Valley |website=[[CBS Interactive]] |date=August 19, 2013 |access-date=December 24, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207075546/http://www.metacritic.com/music/paradise-valley/john-mayer/critic-reviews |archive-date=December 7, 2013 |url-status=live }}</ref>—debuted at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 chart, with first-week sales of 145,560 copies in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitsdailydouble.com/sales/salescht.cgi |title=Building Album Sales Chart |website=HITS Daily Double |access-date=August 28, 2013 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915012320/http://www.hitsdailydouble.com/sales/salescht.cgi |archive-date=September 15, 2014 }}</ref> Mayer embarked on a tour, his first in three years, in support of ''Born and Raised'' and ''Paradise Valley''. The American leg of the tour ran from July to December 2013 with [[Interscope Records|Interscope]] recording artist [[Phillip Phillips]] serving as the supporting act.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Schneider|first=Marc|title=John Mayer Announces First Tour in 3 Years|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1554197/john-mayer-announces-first-tour-in-3-years|magazine=Billboard|access-date=December 24, 2013|date=March 21, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108194945/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1554197/john-mayer-announces-first-tour-in-3-years|archive-date=January 8, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|title=Katy Perry, John Mayer Kiss Onstage: Watch Their Live 'Who You Love' Duet|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1719266/katy-perry-john-mayer-onstage-kiss-video.jhtml|work=MTV|access-date=December 24, 2013|date=December 18, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220210807/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1719266/katy-perry-john-mayer-onstage-kiss-video.jhtml|archive-date=December 20, 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref> The tour visited Australia in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bella|first=Sarah|title=John Mayer Announces Headlining Australian Tour Dates, April 2014|url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/john-mayer-announces-headlining-australian-tour-dates-april-2014/|website=Music Feeds|access-date=December 24, 2013|date=October 16, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140123073813/http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/john-mayer-announces-headlining-australian-tour-dates-april-2014/|archive-date=January 23, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>

During a concert in [[Adelaide, Australia|Adelaide]], Mayer covered the Beyoncé song "[[XO (song)#John Mayer version|XO]]" .<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2014/04/15/video-john-mayer-covers-beyonce-xo/|title=John Mayer Covers Beyoncé's 'XO'|work=Rap-Up|date=April 15, 2014|access-date=June 25, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140806105034/http://www.rap-up.com/2014/04/15/video-john-mayer-covers-beyonce-xo/|archive-date=August 6, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> One month later, on May 22, he released a studio version of the song on his [[SoundCloud]] account.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a573141/john-mayer-unveils-acoustic-cover-of-beyonces-xo.html|title=John Mayer unveils acoustic cover of Beyoncé's 'XO'|publisher=Digital Spy. Hearst Corporation|first=Tom|last=Eames|date=May 23, 2014|access-date=May 23, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523212707/http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a573141/john-mayer-unveils-acoustic-cover-of-beyonces-xo.html|archive-date=May 23, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> It was made available for digital download by Columbia Records on May 27, 2014, through the iTunes Store.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/xo-single/id881555962|title=XO – Single by John Mayer|date=May 27, 2014|publisher=iTunes Store. Apple Inc|location=United States|access-date=May 27, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813072417/https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/xo-single/id881555962|archive-date=August 13, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> For the week ending June 1, 2014, Mayer's version debuted at number 90 on the US ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart and number 13 on the US [[Hot Rock Songs]] chart.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/6113840/john-mayers-beyonce-cover-soars-onto-hot-rock-songs-chart|title=John Mayer's Beyonce Cover Soars Onto Hot Rock Songs 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100?page=8 |title=June 14, 2014: The Hot 100 |magazine=Billboard |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140704070039/http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100?page=8 |page=9 |archive-date=July 4, 2014 |url-status=dead}}</ref> On the Canadian Hot 100, "XO" peaked at a position of 76.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=John Mayer Chart History (Canadian Hot 100) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/john-mayer/chart-history/can/ |magazine=Billboard}}</ref> The single number 95 on the [[Single Top 100|Dutch Singles Chart]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hung |first1=Steffen |title=John Mayer - XO (in Dutch) |url=https://dutchcharts.nl/showitem.asp?interpret=John+Mayer&titel=XO&cat=s |website=Dutch Charts}}</ref> In the UK, it peaked at 115 on the UK Singles Chart.<ref>{{cite
