In February 2015, Mayer performed alongside [[Ed Sheeran]] at the [[57th Annual Grammy Awards|Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Flanagan|first1=Andrew|title=Grammys 2015: Ed Sheeran Performs 'Thinking Out Loud' with Questlove, Herbie Hancock, John Mayer|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/grammys-2015/grammy-performances/6465571/grammys-2015-ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-herbie-hancock-john-mayer-questlove|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=August 7, 2015|date=February 8, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150729075854/http://www.billboard.com/articles/grammys-2015/grammy-performances/6465571/grammys-2015-ed-sheeran-thinking-out-loud-herbie-hancock-john-mayer-questlove|archive-date=July 29, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> As of March, Mayer said he was taking break from working on a "deeply personal new album".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=Ryan|title=John Mayer: 'My High-Speed Crash Was an Intellectual One'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/john-mayer-my-high-speed-crash-was-an-intellectual-one-20150309|website=[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]|date=March 9, 2015|access-date=September 1, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170804234946/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/john-mayer-my-high-speed-crash-was-an-intellectual-one-20150309|archive-date=August 4, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> Mayer also recounted that in 2011 he happened upon a song by the [[Grateful Dead]] while listening to [[Pandora Radio|Pandora]], and that soon the band's music was all he would listen to.<ref name=deadtour>{{cite magazine|title = John Mayer Talks Grateful Dead Legacy, Fare Thee Well and Learning to Play 'A Universe of Great Songs'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6655956/john-mayer-grateful-dead-and-company-interview|magazine = Billboard|date = August 5, 2015|access-date = November 18, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114163602/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6655956/john-mayer-grateful-dead-and-company-interview|archive-date = November 14, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In February 2015, while guest hosting ''[[The Late Late Show (Ireland)|The Late Late Show]]'', Mayer invited Grateful Dead guitar player [[Bob Weir]] to join him in a studio performance. While Weir, [[Phil Lesh]], [[Mickey Hart]] and [[Bill Kreutzmann]] (surviving members of the Grateful Dead) were preparing for their [[Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead]] tour with [[Trey Anastasio]], Mayer began practicing the band's catalog of songs. That August, Mayer, Weir, Kreutzmann, and Hart formed the group [[Dead & Company]], along with [[Jeff Chimenti]] and [[Oteil Burbridge]], and began a fall tour in the United States.<ref>{{cite magazine|last1=Halperin|first1=Shirley|title=The Grateful Dead Is Resurrected Once More, This Time With John Mayer: Exclusive|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6655898/grateful-dead-john-mayer-show-tour|magazine=Billboard|access-date=August 7, 2015|date=August 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150807063753/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/grateful-dead/6655898/grateful-dead-john-mayer-show-tour|archive-date=August 7, 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> The tour was well received (''Billboard'' called it "magical"),<ref name= NYT-Launch16/> and they continued to tour the US into 2016.<ref name=NYT-Launch16/> Although Lesh has declined to join Dead & Company, Mayer also performed with [[Phil Lesh and Friends]] at Terrapin Crossroads in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |title=John MAyer with Phil Lesh & Friends at Terrapin Crossroads |url=https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads |website=Jambase |access-date=September 10, 2018 |date=August 6, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828071145/https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads |archive-date=August 28, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>

As a result of his touring with Dead & Company, Mayer postponed working on his next studio album until January 2016, with plans to finish it by the end of the year.<ref>{{cite news|title=John Mayer grateful for his time with Dead & Company|url=http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article92189277.html|newspaper=The Sacramento Bee|access-date=July 29, 2016|last1=Sculley|first1=Alan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923105650/http://www.sacbee.com/entertainment/music-news-reviews/article92189277.html|archive-date=September 23, 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> On November 17, 2016, Mayer released "[[Love on the Weekend]]" as the lead single from his EP ''[[The Search for Everything: Wave One]]'', which was then released on January 20, 2017.<ref>{{cite magazine|author=Danielle Jackson|url=https://ew.com/music/2017/01/03/john-mayer-release-plans-new-music/|title=John Mayer announces release plans for new music|magazine=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=January 3, 2017|access-date=May 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170322204617/http://ew.com/music/2017/01/03/john-mayer-release-plans-new-music/|archive-date=March 22, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> A second EP, ''[[The Search for Everything: Wave Two]]'', was released on February 24, 2017, along with the single "Still Feel Like Your Man". The album ''[[The Search for Everything]]'' was released on April 14, 2017, and was promoted by a third single titled "In the Blood", released on May 1, 2017,<ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer - In the Blood (Radio Edit)|url=http://daily.plaympe.com/john-mayer-in-the-blood-radio-edit/|publisher=Daily Play MPE|access-date=May 3, 2017|date=May 2, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170507160950/http://daily.plaympe.com/john-mayer-in-the-blood-radio-edit/|archive-date=May 7, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer ships "In the Blood" to country studio|date=May 2, 2017 |url=http://theboot.com/john-mayer-country-single-in-the-blood/|publisher=The Boot|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419121030/http://theboot.com/john-mayer-country-single-in-the-blood/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> and by [[The Search for Everything World Tour]] from March to October of the same year.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-maps-out-search-for-everything-world-tour-w463576|title=John Mayer Maps Out 'Search for Everything' World Tour|last1=Kreps|first1=Daniel|date=January 30, 2017|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=Wenner Media LLC|access-date=May 22, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170516162922/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-maps-out-search-for-everything-world-tour-w463576|archive-date=May 16, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

Mayer also continued touring with Dead & Company during the [[Dead & Company Summer Tour 2017|summer]]<ref name=Dead2017>{{cite web |url=http://www.jambase.com/article/dead-company-announces-summer-tour-2017 |title=Dead & Company Announce Summer Tour 2017 |work=Jam Base |date=December 1, 2016 |access-date=February 24, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203151802/http://www.jambase.com/article/dead-company-announces-summer-tour-2017 |archive-date=December 3, 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> and [[Dead & Company Fall Tour 2017|fall]]<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Dead & Company detail fall tour|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/dead-company-detail-fall-tour-w501739|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=September 7, 2017|date=September 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171225174116/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/dead-company-detail-fall-tour-w501739|archive-date=December 25, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> of 2017. On December 5, during the Fall Tour, his appendix burst, resulting in an emergency [[appendectomy]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/05/entertainment/john-mayer-appendectomy/index.html|title=John Mayer recovering from emergency appendectomy|last1=Gonzales|first1=Sandra|date=December 6, 2017|website=[[CNN]]|access-date=April 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409110211/https://edition.cnn.com/2017/12/05/entertainment/john-mayer-appendectomy/index.html|archive-date=April 9, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> and the postponement of the remaining tour dates to February 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/dead-company-announces-2018-tour-dates|title=Dead & Company Announces New Dates For Postponed Shows|work=JamBase|date=December 8, 2017|access-date=April 9, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180409171541/https://www.jambase.com/article/dead-company-announces-2018-tour-dates|archive-date=April 9, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In January 2018, Dead & Company announced their [[Dead & Company Summer Tour 2018]].<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Wandera|last=Hussein|date=January 18, 2018|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8094919/dead-and-company-tour-2018-dates|title=Dead & Company Announce 19-City Summertime Tour|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=January 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180118164256/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/8094919/dead-and-company-tour-2018-dates|archive-date=January 18, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== ''Sob Rock'' (2018–present) ===
{{main|Sob Rock}}
On May 10, 2018, Mayer released the single "[[New Light (John Mayer song)|New Light]]", co-produced by [[No I.D.]] and Mayer himself.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/john-mayer-and-no-id-share-new-song-new-light-listen/|title=John Mayer and No I.D. Share New Song "New Light": Listen|last1=Kim|first1=Michelle|date=May 10, 2018|website=[[Pitchfork (magazine)|Pitchfork]]|access-date=May 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511081207/https://pitchfork.com/news/john-mayer-and-no-id-share-new-song-new-light-listen/|archive-date=May 11, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In an interview with [[Zane Lowe]] for [[Apple Music]] on the release day, he announced "more new music" for 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhbpo5Bv4Vs|title=John Mayer: 'New Light' Premiere &#124; Beats 1 &#124; Apple Music|date=May 10, 2018|via=YouTube|access-date=May 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180531154744/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bhbpo5Bv4Vs|archive-date=May 31, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> During his performance at the iHeartRadio Theater on October 24, 2018, he premiered a song titled "I Guess I Just Feel Like".<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8481727/john-mayer-new-song-i-guess-i-just-feel-like-listen-iheartradio-theater-concert-recap|title=John Mayer Debuts New Song 'I Guess I Just Feel Like,' Plus More Highlights From LA iHeartRadio Theater Set|last1=Atkinson|first1=Katie|date=October 25, 2018|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=December 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181217135807/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8481727/john-mayer-new-song-i-guess-i-just-feel-like-listen-iheartradio-theater-concert-recap|archive-date=December 17, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> On December 12, 2018, he announced a world tour for 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/music/109277264/john-mayer-kicks-off-world-tour-in-new-zealand|title=John Mayer to kick off world tour in New Zealand, 2019|date=December 12, 2018|website=[[stuff.co.nz]]|access-date=December 12, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181215223154/https://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/music/109277264/john-mayer-kicks-off-world-tour-in-new-zealand|archive-date=December 15, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> Mayer released two singles in 2019; the previously played "I Guess I Just Feel Like" on February 22, and "Carry Me Away" on September 6.

During an episode of John Mayer's show "Current Mood" on March 15, 2020, he revealed that he was in the process of writing and recording songs for a new album.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-coronavirus-anxiety-quarantines-current-mood/|title=John Mayer Talks New Album, Anxiety, COVID-19, More Live On 'Current Mood' [Watch]|work=Live For Live Music|last=Kawas|first=Kel|date=March 16, 2020|access-date=October 7, 2020}}</ref> In early 2021, he stated that the album was completely finished as he began posting snippets of new songs on [[TikTok]] ahead of release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-new-album-preview-tiktok/|title=John Mayer Shares Preview Of New Album On TikTok [Watch]|work=Live For Live Music|last=O'Brien|first=Andrew|date=March 28, 2021|access-date=March 28, 2021}}</ref> In an interview with [[Kerwin Frost]], Mayer hinted at an April release for the album.<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/iWgyprxp1wk Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20210320112039/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iWgyprxp1wk Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{Citation|title=KERWIN FROST TALKS TO JOHN MAYER|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iWgyprxp1wk|language=en|access-date=April 4, 2021}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Later, the date was pushed back. On June 1, 2021, Mayer officially announced his eighth album ''[[Sob Rock]]'' and on June 4, released the lead single, "[[Last Train Home (John Mayer song)|Last Train Home]]" along with an accompanying music video. The album was released on July 16, 2021, as well as a music video for the song, "Shot In The Dark". The track list included previously released singles "New Light", "I Guess I Just Feel Like" and "Carry Me Away". "Carry Me Away" was slightly reworked production-wise to fit the album's 1980s aesthetic.

''Rolling Stone''. (903):28.</ref>

==Other ventures==
===Dead & Company===
{{main|Dead & Company}}
Since 2015, Mayer has been touring with [[Bob Weir]], [[Bill Kreutzmann]] and [[Mickey Hart]] of the [[Grateful Dead]]. Founding bassist [[Phil Lesh]] has notably declined to participate in the project, although he has performed with Mayer on a few occasions since Dead & Company began.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer with Phil Lesh & Friends at Terrapin Crossroads|url=https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads|website=Jambase|access-date=September 10, 2018|date=August 6, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828071145/https://www.jambase.com/article/john-mayer-with-phil-lesh-friends-at-terrapin-crossroads|archive-date=August 28, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> The role of bassist in Dead & Company has instead been played by [[Oteil Burbridge]] of the [[Allman Brothers Band]]. [[Jeff Chimenti]], who has toured with the various spin-offs of the Dead since the 1990s, is the group's keyboardist. 
 
Although Mayer had been familiar with the music of the Grateful Dead since at least high school, he began to develop a strong interest in their music in 2011 after hearing their song ''[[Althea (Grateful Dead song)|Althea]]'' by chance on [[Pandora radio]]. In 2015, while the Dead's ''[[Fare Thee Well: Celebrating 50 Years of the Grateful Dead|Fare Thee Well]]'' shows with [[Trey Anastasio]] were also being planned, Mayer performed "Althea" with Weir on [[The Late Late Show (U.S. TV series)|The Late Late Show]], along with "[[Truckin']]". Weir was impressed with Mayer's take on the material and began planning to work with him after the Fare Thee Well shows, despite them being billed as something of finale for the band and its legacy. Weir discussed the genesis of the band and his thoughts about working with Mayer in an interview with ''Rolling Stone'' in 2016:

{{Blockquote|I was doing preliminary get-togethers with Trey, kicking around the material. Trey is also a monster musician. If I had to make a broad categorization, John is a classicist by nature. Trey is more of an iconoclast. They're both explorers, someone who's happy to break tradition. Juxtaposing Trey's take on the material with the insights John brings got me looking at all of the songs afresh.

I look forward to playing with Trey again, any old time. But I am really eager to get back out with John-boy and chase the music around, get to know each other. When that dream came to me, it was at about that point that I started to realize that I was feeling comfortable with knowing that John had moved, musically speaking – being able to intuit the songs. We were feeling each other out on a new level, several bars down the road.<ref name="FRICKE">{{cite magazine |last1=Fricke |first1=David |title=Bob Weir on Dead & Company's Future, John Mayer's Strengths |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/bob-weir-on-dead-companys-future-john-mayers-classicist-style-50971/ |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=16 October 2018 |date=31 May 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828071449/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/bob-weir-on-dead-companys-future-john-mayers-classicist-style-50971/ |archive-date=August 28, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>}}

The thought of pop singer Mayer stepping in for [[Jerry Garcia]] was met with some initial skepticism by both fans and music critics, but the shows have since been well received.<ref name="uproxx">{{cite web |title=In Praise Of John Mayer's Unlikely Second Life As A Jam Band Hero |url=https://uproxx.com/music/john-mayer-dead-and-company-jam-band-reinvention/ |website=UPROXX |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=July 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180828134359/https://uproxx.com/music/john-mayer-dead-and-company-jam-band-reinvention/ |archive-date=August 28, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> The band continues to tour 2022 and has considered recording a studio album consisting of songs from the Grateful Dead catalog and potentially some originals. In a 2017 interview with ''Rolling Stone'', Lesh praised the band's performances and explained his decision not to take part:
{{Blockquote|"I think they're doing a great job. They're bringing the music to the people just like we always wanted to do, and I commend them for it. I hope they're having a good time. It's not something I could do myself, I'm done with that kind of touring.'<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Phil Lesh on Grateful Dead "Long Strange Trip" doc: "it's not the whole story."|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/phil-lesh-on-grateful-dead-doc-long-strange-trip-its-not-the-whole-story-110241/|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=10 September 2018|date=May 25, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180910095121/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/phil-lesh-on-grateful-dead-doc-long-strange-trip-its-not-the-whole-story-110241/|archive-date=September 10, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>}}

===Author===
With the June 2004 issue of ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', Mayer began a column called "Music Lessons with John Mayer".<ref>Newman, Melinda (April 17, 2004), "John Mayer Tries Hand At New Instrument". ''Billboard''. '''116''' (16):13.</ref> Each article featured a lesson and his views on various topics, both of personal and popular interest. In the August 2005 issue, he invited readers to create music for orphaned lyrics he had written.<ref name=contest>Mayer, John (September 2005), [http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 "The Giveaway: John Mayer's Songwriting Contest"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105182915/http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 |date=November 5, 2013 }} ''Esquire''. '''144''' (3):80.</ref> The winner was Tim Fagan of [[Los Angeles]] as announced in the following January's issue.<ref name=winner>Mayer, John (January 2006), [http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 "Tim Fagan Is A Winner"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105182915/http://www.esquire.com/features/music/ESQ0106MUSIC_38 |date=November 5, 2013 }}. ''Esquire''. '''145''' (1): p. 38.</ref>

As social media gained momentum in the 2000s, Mayer became increasingly active online, and maintained four blogs: a [[Myspace]] page, a blog at his official site, another at Honeyee.com, one at [[tumblr]], and a [[photoblog]] at StunningNikon.com. He was particularly prolific on [[Twitter]], where he was noted for authoring his own posts, and he amassed 3.7 million followers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/SHOWBIZ/Music/09/14/john.mayer.twitter/index.html|title=Mayer to tweet no more - CNN.com|website=www.cnn.com|language=en|access-date=April 14, 2020}}</ref><ref name=MandS/> Although his posts often dealt with career-related matters, they also included jokes, videos, photos, and eventually what he called the "maintenance of vapor"—or misguided, personal responses to the media.<ref name=DIEHL/> On January 23, 2008, he posted the quote "There is danger in theoretical speculation of battle, in prejudice, in false reasoning, in pride, in [[wikt:braggadocio|braggadocio]]. There is one safe resource, the return to nature.";{{cref|c}} all the previous blog entries were deleted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmayer.com/blog/john/200801 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102234004/http://www.johnmayer.com/blog/john/200801 |url-status=dead |archive-date=January 2, 2008 |title=johnmayer.com |access-date=May 2, 2017}}</ref> On September 14, 2010, he deleted his personal Twitter account.<ref name=DIEHL/>

In the mid-2000s, he did comedy sporadically,<ref name="Daly">Daly, Steven (December 2009), [http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/cover-stars/200912/singer-musician-cover-star-half-of-my-heart-john-mayer?currentPage=6 "John Mayer Thinks With His Pick"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091128055033/http://www.details.com/celebrities-entertainment/cover-stars/200912/singer-musician-cover-star-half-of-my-heart-john-mayer?currentPage=6|date=November 28, 2009}}. ''Details''. Retrieved February 8, 2010.</ref> making random appearances at the famed [[Comedy Cellar]] in New York and at other venues.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Lehner |first1=Marla |title=John Mayer Performs Raunchy Stand-Up |url=https://people.com/celebrity/john-mayer-performs-raunchy-stand-up/ |website=PEOPLE.com |access-date=May 6, 2022 |language=en |date=May 22, 2007}}</ref> He stated that it helped him write better, but that increased media attention made him too careful in his technique.<ref name=RS06/> He has since said he has no plans to return to it.<ref name=patrickdoyle/>

===Watch collector===
Mayer is an avid collector of watches, a pastime that he says keeps him "sane". His collection—which he values in the "tens of millions" of dollars<ref name=wrist/>—includes a [[Patek Philippe & Co.#Most expensive|Patek Philippe with a Sky Moon Tourbillion]], a [[Rolex GMT Master]] 116710 BLNR, and an [[International Watch Company|IWC]] Big Pilot Ref 5002, his signature watch.<ref name=wrist/><ref>Clymer, Benjamin and Holloway, Will (September 25, 2013), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/video-talking-watches-with-john-mayer "Talking Watches With John Mayer"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402164412/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/video-talking-watches-with-john-mayer |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Hodinkee. Retrieved March 25, 2015.</ref> He has also served as a juror at the Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Genève, a competition rewarding timepieces that champion the values of [[Swiss made|Swiss-made]] watches<ref name=wrist/> and writes a column for the [[horology]] website [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/john-mayer-chanel-watch-box Hodinkee].<ref>Williams, Alex (December 20, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/22/fashion/Hodinkee-Wristwatches-Benjamin-Clymer.html "The High Priest of Horology"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170222012136/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/22/fashion/Hodinkee-Wristwatches-Benjamin-Clymer.html |date=February 22, 2017 }}. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved March 24, 2015.</ref> In his column for January 16, 2015, he wrote an open letter to the watch brand IWC, encouraging it to "embrace [its] heritage, scale the product line down in terms of model variants, and simplify the design language".<ref>Mayer, John (January 16, 2015), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-iwc-from-john-mayer "An Open Letter To IWC, From John Mayer"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905113608/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-iwc-from-john-mayer |date=September 5, 2015 }}. Hodinkee. Retrieved March 24, 2015.</ref> IWC replied, defending the changes they've made over the years, saying, "We have a wonderful past, it is true—but in admiring what we achieved thus far, we hope you will feel encouraged to look forward to what we achieve in the future".<ref>(January 17, 2015), [http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-john-mayer--from-iwc "An Open Letter To John Mayer, From IWC"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150503011359/http://www.hodinkee.com/blog/an-open-letter-to-john-mayer--from-iwc |date=May 3, 2015 }}. Hondikee. Retrieved May 4, 2015.</ref>

In March 2024, Mayer was appointed with the title of "Creative Conduit" at [[Audemars Piguet]], to help facilitate the connection between the watch brand and collectors.<ref>{{Cite web |title=As a long-time watch lover, today is a very special moment in my life. |url=https://www.instagram.com/johnmayer/p/C4OSTOiOnPw/?hl=en |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Instagram}}</ref> In addition to the new role, Mayer and AP also announced a new limited-edition collaborative Perpetual Calendar Royal Oak model (Ref. 26574BC.OO.1220BC.02), dubbed the "John Mayer" and designed by its namesake.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hartov |first=Oren |date=2024-04-20 |title=Inside John Mayer's Star-Studded Audemars Piguet Launch Party |url=https://www.gq.com/story/watches-of-the-week-4-20-24 |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=GQ |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Pener |first=Degen |date=2024-04-18 |title=John Mayer Designed a New Watch That He Predicts "Will Outlive Me" |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lifestyle/style/john-mayer-audemars-piguet-perpetual-calendar-watch-launch-celebrity-guests-1235876452/ |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=The Hollywood Reporter |language=en-US}}</ref> It features a "Crystal Sky" faceted blue dial, a white-gold case and bracelet, and is limited to 200 pieces.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kauzlarich |first=Mark |title=Hands-On: The Audemars Piguet Royal Oak Perpetual Calendar John Mayer Limited Edition (Live Pics) |url=https://www.hodinkee.com/articles/hands-on-john-mayer-audemars-piguet-royal-oak |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Hodinkee |language=en}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=2024-03-13 |title=John Mayer's Collaboration With Audemars Piguet Doesn't Disappoint |url=https://www.esquire.com/style/mens-accessories/a60191174/audemars-piguet-john-mayer-royal-oak-perpetual-calendar/ |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Esquire |language=en-US}}</ref>

===''Current Mood''===
During an appearance on the ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' show in September 2018, Mayer showed a trailer for his new Instagram Live show.<ref>{{cite AV media | title =John Mayer Debuts Trailer for New Instagram Show | publisher =ABC | location =Los Angeles, California |url=https://abc.go.com/shows/jimmy-kimmel-live/video/featured/VDKA5285132 | access-date =November 12, 2018 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113025617/https://abc.go.com/shows/jimmy-kimmel-live/video/featured/VDKA5285132 | archive-date =November 13, 2018 | url-status=live }}</ref> The show, entitled ''Current Mood'', debuted on his [[IGTV]] account on Sunday evening on September 30, 2018. Episodes have continued to air on that schedule on a weekly basis.<ref name="Burks">{{cite web |last1=Burks |first1=Tosten |title=Watch Thundercat and John Mayer Perform "Them Changes" on Instagram |url=https://www.spin.com/2018/10/thundercat-john-mayer-them-changes-instagram/ |website=Spin |access-date=November 12, 2018 |date=October 29, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181113025511/https://www.spin.com/2018/10/thundercat-john-mayer-them-changes-instagram/ |archive-date=November 13, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> Guests have included [[Maggie Rogers]], [[Halsey (singer)|Halsey]], [[B. J. Novak|B.J. Novak]], [[Dave Chappelle]], [[Charlie Puth]], [[Finneas O'Connell|Finneas]], [[Larry David#Personal life|Cazzie David]], and [[Thundercat (musician)|Thundercat]].<ref name="Catucci">{{cite magazine |last1=Catucci |first1=Nick |title=How John Mayer Got a Grip on Fame -- and Intends to Bring 'Truth' Back to Music |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8483692/john-mayer-billboard-cover-story |magazine=Billboard |access-date=November 12, 2018 |date=November 8, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181109035458/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop/8483692/john-mayer-billboard-cover-story |archive-date=November 9, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> Mayer's latest season of ''Current Mood'' began on Sunday November 18, 2019, with guest [[Shawn Mendes]] and surprise feature with [[Camila Cabello]] on his first episode. For Current Mood Mayer coined notable jingles including "Camila Camendes", "CVS Bag", and "Drone Shot of My Yacht".

=== Life with John Mayer ===
In October 2023, Mayer announced a new real-time satellite radio channel on [[Sirius XM]], titled "Life with John Mayer".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Introducing "Life With John Mayer," my new @siriusxm channel launching in November. |url=https://www.instagram.com/johnmayer/p/Cx5iWPXsanY/?hl=en |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Instagram}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Want to listen to music curated by John Mayer 24/7, 365? Good – a new SiriusXM channel is launching for just that |url=https://guitar.com/news/music-news/john-mayer-life-with-john-mayer-siriusxm-channel/ |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Guitar.com {{!}} All Things Guitar |language=en-GB}}</ref> The year-round channel features music curated by Mayer, including Mayer's classics, collaborations, and never released material, along with selected music from all genres.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Aniftos |first=Rania |date=2023-10-02 |title=John Mayer to Launch a New SiriusXM Channel |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/john-mayer-siriusxm-channel-1235431227/ |access-date=2024-05-15 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-03-02 |title=Meet Sirius XM's new odd couple: Warren Buffett and John Mayer |url=https://www.morningstar.com/news/marketwatch/20240302277/meet-sirius-xms-new-odd-couple-warren-buffett-and-john-mayer |access-date=2024-05-15 |website=Morningstar, Inc. |language=en}}</ref>

===Appearances in the media===
In 2004, Mayer hosted a one-shot, half-hour comedy special on [[VH1]] titled ''John Mayer Has a TV Show'', with antics including wearing a bear suit while anonymously teasing concertgoers in the parking lot outside one of his concerts.

[[Image:John Mayer Macworld.jpg|thumb|215px|right|January 2005, left to right: [[David Ryan Harris]], John Mayer and [[Steve Jobs]] at [[Macworld Conference & Expo|Macworld 11]], SF [[Moscone Center]].]]
[[Steve Jobs]] invited Mayer to perform during [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]'s annual keynote address at the [[Macworld Conference & Expo]] in January 2004 as Jobs introduced the music production software [[GarageBand]].<ref>Deitrich, Andy (February 2, 2004) [https://arstechnica.com/reviews/apps/garageband.ars "Making music for the non-musically inclined"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211104948/http://arstechnica.com/reviews/apps/garageband.ars |date=December 11, 2008 }}. ''Ars Technica''. Retrieved June 12, 2007.</ref> Mayer became a fixture of the event, including at the 2007 [[iPhone]] announcement.<ref>Krazit, Tom (January 9, 2007). [http://news.cnet.com/Live+Macworld+coverage/2061-10793_3-6148381.html "Live Macworld coverage"]. ''CNET''. Retrieved June 12, 2007.</ref> [[Volkswagen]] concluded a deal with instrument manufacturer [[First Act]] to include a GarageMaster electric guitar that was playable through the stereo system of six of their 2007 models; Mayer (along with [[Slash (musician)|Slash]] and [[Christopher Guest]]) were selected to endorse the campaign and were featured playing the guitar in ads.<ref name=VWR>''Billboard'' staff (October 3, 2006), [https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57074/volkswagen-cars-to-feature-first-act-guitars "Volkswagen Cars To Feature First Act Guitars"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403053314/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57074/volkswagen-cars-to-feature-first-act-guitars |date=April 3, 2015 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved March 25, 2015.</ref> Mayer used and endorsed the [[BlackBerry|BlackBerry Curve]].

Mayer made many appearances on talk shows and other television programs, most notably on a ''[[Chappelle's Show]]'' comedy skit, the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' and on the final episode of ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]''. Mayer appeared with [[Rob Dyrdek]] in the MTV show ''[[Rob Dyrdek's Fantasy Factory]]''. Mayer wrote the theme song to the [[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|OWN network]] show ''Rollin' with Zach'', which features [[Zach Anner]].<ref>{{cite web|title='Rollin' With Zach' and 'The Ambush Cook' This December on OWN|url=http://www.oprah.com/pressroom/Rollin-With-Zach-and-The-Ambush-Cook-This-December-on-OWN|website=Oprah|access-date=February 18, 2013 |date=November 11, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130511014345/http://www.oprah.com/pressroom/Rollin-With-Zach-and-The-Ambush-Cook-This-December-on-OWN |archive-date=May 11, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> CBS invited him to guest host ''[[The Late Late Show (U.S.)|The Late Late Show]]'' in early 2015 on three dates, February 4–6, after the retirement of [[Craig Ferguson]].<ref>{{cite web|title=CBS Taps 'The Talk' and Guest Hosts To Fill 'Late Late Show'|url=https://variety.com/2014/tv/news/cbs-taps-the-talk-and-guest-hosts-to-fill-late-late-show-1201365480/|access-date=December 9, 2014|work=Variety|date=November 26, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141210222837/http://variety.com/2014/tv/news/cbs-taps-the-talk-and-guest-hosts-to-fill-late-late-show-1201365480/|archive-date=December 10, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> He appeared as a guest star on the fourth episode of the [[Impractical Jokers (season 10)|tenth season]] of the [[TruTV]] show [[Impractical Jokers]] in 2023.<ref>{{Citation |last=Jost |first=Casey |title=John Mayer |date=2023-03-02 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt26626081/ |access-date=2023-10-31 |series=Impractical Jokers |others=James Murray, Brian Quinn, Sal Vulcano}}</ref>

Mayer makes a cameo as a truck driver in the 2014 comedy horror film ''[[Zombeavers]]''.<ref>Zeitchik, Steven (April 21, 2014), "[https://latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-tribeca-2014-zombeavers-movie-sharknado-20140421-story.html "Tribeca 2014: 'Zombeavers,' 'Sharknado's' newest friend"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-tribeca-2014-zombeavers-movie-sharknado-20140421-story.html |date=October 17, 2015 }}. ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved May 20, 2015.</ref> In the 2015 film ''[[Get Hard]]'', he played a version of himself who is disgusted with the "monetization of the creative process".<ref name=Mallenbaum>Mallenbaum, Carly (March 30, 2015), [http://entertainthis.usatoday.com/2015/03/30/john-mayer-cameo-get-hard/ "John Mayer: The king of the cameo"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403023020/http://entertainthis.usatoday.com/2015/03/30/john-mayer-cameo-get-hard/ |date=April 3, 2015 }}. USA Today. Retrieved April 9, 2015.</ref> Mayer also had a small role in the 2022 film ''[[Vengeance (2022 film)|Vengeance]]'', playing a friend of the lead character.

==Instruments and equipment==
John Mayer is a guitar collector and has collaborated with elite guitar companies to design his own instruments. He owns over 200 guitars.<ref name=RS06/>

In 2003, [[C. F. Martin & Company|Martin Guitars]] gave Mayer his own signature model acoustic guitar called the OM-28 John Mayer.<ref name=OM-28>(2003). [http://www.harmonycentral.com/news/john-mayer-receives-signature-martin-om-guitar "John Mayer Receives Signature Martin OM Guitar"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402153239/http://www.harmonycentral.com/news/john-mayer-receives-signature-martin-om-guitar |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Retrieved January 29, 2007.</ref> The guitar was limited to a run of only 404, an Atlanta area code.<ref name=martin>''Sounding Board Newsletter'' contributor (2003) [http://www.martinguitar.com/model/item/1259-john-mayer-signature-om.html "John Mayer Signature OM"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112812/http://www.martinguitar.com/model/item/1259-john-mayer-signature-om.html |date=April 2, 2015 }} Martin Guitar. Retrieved March 25, 2015</ref> This model was followed by the release of two [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]] signature [[Fender Stratocaster|Stratocaster]] electric guitars, beginning in 2005. A third Stratocaster, finished in charcoal frost metallic paint with a racing stripe, was also a limited-release, with only 100 guitars made. In January 2006, Martin Guitars released the Martin OMJM John Mayer acoustic guitar. The guitar was intended to have many of the attributes of the Martin OM-28 John Mayer but with a more affordable price tag.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/08/john-mayers-sig.html |title=Fretbase, John Mayer's Signature Acoustic Guitar – the Martin OMJM (2008) |website=Fretbase.com |date=August 4, 2008 |access-date=July 24, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081023154758/http://www.fretbase.com/fretbase/2008/08/john-mayers-sig.html |archive-date=October 23, 2008 }}</ref> In August 2006, Fender started manufacturing SERIES II John Mayer Stratocasters.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}}

In January 2007, Two Rock collaborated with Mayer on custom-designed amps. Only 25 (all signed by Mayer himself) were made available to the public,<ref>[http://two-rock.com/products/mayer "John Mayer Signature"] Two-Rock. Retrieved May 10, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502014433/http://two-rock.com/products/mayer |date=May 2, 2007 }}</ref> along with a 500-run John Mayer signature Fender Stratocaster in Cypress-Mica. Included in the limited Cypress-Mica model was the INCSvsJM [[gig bag]], on which Mayer collaborated on the in-case designs. In 2006, Mayer was estimated to have more than 200 guitars in his personal collection.<ref name=RS06/>
[[File:John Mayer in Cleveland.jpg|thumb|Mayer playing his signature Black1 Stratocaster in 2008]]
John Mayer's most iconic guitar is the "Black1". Conceived after the [[Heavier Things]] tour, Mayer went to Fender Custom Shop with the desire to build a guitar.<ref name=micktaylor/> He was inspired by guitars of famous players the likes of [[Rory Gallagher]] and [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]].<ref name="youtube.com">Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/gLMnWxw1Qpg Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130811004456/http://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=related&v=gLMnWxw1Qpg&rl=yes&hl=en&gl=US&client=mv-google&guid= Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gLMnWxw1Qpg |title=John Mayer - Black One Story |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=January 5, 2012 |access-date=May 2, 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> He sought out masterbuilder John Cruz to help devise the design. In essence, Mayer wanted an all-black version of Stevie Ray Vaughan's "First Wife" Stratocaster.<ref>Archived at [https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211211/luCzeNjs7rE Ghostarchive]{{cbignore}} and the [https://web.archive.org/web/20200219141750/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luCzeNjs7rE&gl=US&hl=en Wayback Machine]{{cbignore}}: {{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=luCzeNjs7rE |title=Fender Custom Shop Road Show With John Cruz - John Mayer |publisher=YouTube |date=December 3, 2015 |access-date=May 2, 2017}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The guitar is heavily "relic'd" to specs very similar to the guitar used by Stevie Ray Vaughan. The Black1 includes a mint pickguard, custom wound pickups, gold hardware, and gold tuners from the SRV Tribute Stratocaster. It was the principal guitar on the ''Continuum'' album. It was notably used on tracks such as "I Don't Trust Myself With Loving You", and "Bold as Love".<ref name="youtube.com"/> The Black1 has become a trademark to Mayer's music.

The [[Fender Custom Shop]] made a limited run of 83 replica Black1 Stratocasters, all of which were sold within 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web |last=Laing |first=Rob |url=http://www.musicradar.com/guitarist/fender-custom-shop-john-mayer-black1-340224 |title=Fender Custom Shop John Mayer BLACK1 |work=[[MusicRadar]] |date=December 21, 2010 |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170227013052/http://www.musicradar.com/guitarist/fender-custom-shop-john-mayer-black1-340224 |archive-date=February 27, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> Each one was carefully relic'd by John Cruz. In 2010, Fender announced a production model of Mayer's Black1 guitar.<ref name=micktaylor>Taylor, Mick (May 21, 2010), [http://www.musicradar.com/us/guitarist/john-mayer-interview-251957 "John Mayer interview"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404230439/http://www.musicradar.com/us/guitarist/john-mayer-interview-251957 |date=April 4, 2015 }}. ''Music Radar''. March 29, 2015.</ref> Un-relic'd production versions of the guitar were produced for a limited run of 500 worldwide.<ref>{{cite web |author=Mike Duffy |url=http://www2.fender.com/experience/fender-tone/introducing-the-john-mayer-special-edition-black1-stratocaster-guitar/ |title=Introducing the John Mayer Special Edition BLACK1 Stratocaster® Guitar &#124; Fender Tone |website=Fender.com |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170515184339/http://www2.fender.com/experience/fender-tone/introducing-the-john-mayer-special-edition-black1-stratocaster-guitar/ |archive-date=May 15, 2017 |url-status=dead}}</ref> In addition, full production signature Stratocasters were produced in three-tone sunburst and Olympic White finishes.

In 2014, John Mayer announced that he was no longer a Fender Artist.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://reverb.com/news/john-mayer-announces-split-with-fender |title=John Mayer Announces Split with Fender |website=Reverb.com |date=October 17, 2014 |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827125726/https://reverb.com/news/john-mayer-announces-split-with-fender |archive-date=August 27, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> As a result, his signature line of guitars was pulled from production. In 2015, Mayer announced that he was collaborating with [[PRS Guitars]]. In March 2016, Mayer and PRS revealed their collaborative project, the Super Eagle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.prsguitars.com/supereagle/ |title=PRS Guitars Private Stock Super Eagle |website=PRS Guitars |access-date=May 2, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430172057/http://www.prsguitars.com/supereagle/ |archive-date=April 30, 2017 |url-status=live }}</ref> This was a limited release from PRS's Private Stock line of instruments and each guitar features ultra-grade woods, abalone inlay, JCF Audio preamps, and a hand-signed sticker by glass-artist [[David Adrian Smith|David Smith]]. Only 100 were produced, each retailing for over $10,000.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Mayer's PRS Private Stock Super Eagle guitar takes flight |url=https://www.musicradar.com/news/guitars/john-mayers-prs-private-stock-super-eagle-guitar-takes-flight-635835 |last=Astley-Brown |first=Michael |date=March 15, 2016 |publisher=[[MusicRadar]]}}</ref> In January 2017 at the [[NAMM Show]], PRS and Mayer announced the J-MOD 100 signature amp.<ref>{{cite web|title=J-MOD 100|url=http://www.prsguitars.com/amplifiers/jmod/j_mod_100_2018/|website=PRS Guitars|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419183236/http://www.prsguitars.com/amplifiers/jmod/j_mod_100_2018/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=NAMM 2017: PRS and John Mayer Announce J-MOD 100 Signature Amp|url=https://www.guitarworld.com/gear/namm-2017-prs-and-john-mayer-announce-j-mod-100-signature-amp |magazine=Guitar World|access-date=January 17, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180207003116/https://www.guitarworld.com/gear/namm-2017-prs-and-john-mayer-announce-j-mod-100-signature-amp|archive-date=February 7, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In June 2017, the Super Eagle II was revealed, limited to 120 instruments.<ref>{{cite web |title=PRS Guitars Private Stock Super Eagle II|url=https://prsguitars.com/supereagle2/|website=PRS Guitars|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419003031/http://prsguitars.com/supereagle2/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=PRS Guitars Announces John Mayer Limited Edition Private Stock Super Eagle II|url=http://americansongwriter.com/2017/06/prs-guitars-announces-john-mayer-limited-edition-private-stock-super-eagle-ii/ |magazine=American Songwriter|access-date=June 7, 2017|date=June 7, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170719072101/https://americansongwriter.com/2017/06/prs-guitars-announces-john-mayer-limited-edition-private-stock-super-eagle-ii/|archive-date=July 19, 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>

In January 2018, Martin Guitar announced the limited-release (45 instruments) John Mayer Signature D-45, with list price $14,999.<ref>{{cite web|title=D-45 John Mayer |url=https://www.martinguitar.com/guitars/custom-signature-editions/d-45-john-mayer/|website=martinguitar.com|access-date=April 19, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419140633/https://www.martinguitar.com/guitars/custom-signature-editions/d-45-john-mayer/|archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Martin Announces High-End John Mayer Signature D-45|date=January 4, 2018 |url=https://reverb.com/news/martin-announces-high-end-john-mayer-signature-d-45 |publisher=Reverb|access-date=January 4, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419120637/https://reverb.com/news/martin-announces-high-end-john-mayer-signature-d-45 |archive-date=April 19, 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> In March 2018, Mayer's signature [[PRS Silver Sky|Silver Sky]] model was released by PRS, available in four colors.<ref>{{cite web |title=Silver Sky |url=https://prsguitars.com/electrics/bolton/silver_sky |website=PRS Guitars |access-date=April 19, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180419183247/https://prsguitars.com/electrics/bolton/silver_sky |archive-date=April 19, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |title=PRS Guitars Announces New John Mayer Signature Model: The Silver Sky |url=http://americansongwriter.com/2018/03/prs-guitars-announces-new-john-mayer-signature-model-silver-sky/ |magazine=American Songwriter |access-date=March 6, 2018 |date=March 6, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180314062136/http://americansongwriter.com/2018/03/prs-guitars-announces-new-john-mayer-signature-model-silver-sky/ |archive-date=March 14, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> While ''Music Trade'' called the Silver Sky "derivative", it said that all the elements were "designed from the ground up" and built with "attention to detail".<ref name="gaining">{{cite journal |title=WHY PRS IS GAINING SHARE IN THE GUITAR MARKET |journal=Music Trades |date=October 2018 |volume=116 |issue=9 |pages=56–62}}</ref> While acknowledging its similarity to a Stratocaster, Matt Blackett of ''Guitar Player'' magazine ultimately said, "The Silver Sky absolutely delivers on the promise of being a damn-near-perfect version of this type of guitar." The magazine named its "Editor's Pick".<ref name="blackett">{{cite journal|last1=Blackett |first1=MATT |date=July 2018|title=Silver Sky John Mayer Signature|journal=Guitar Player |volume=52|issue=7|pages=88–89 |url=https://www.guitarplayer.com/gear/prs-sliver-sky-john-mayer-signature |access-date=May 26, 2019}}</ref>

==Reception==
Mayer was featured on the cover of ''Rolling Stone'' (#1020) in February 2007, along with [[John Frusciante]] and [[Derek Trucks]], in an issue lauding the "New Guitar Gods". The cover nicknamed him Slowhand Jr., a reference to Eric Clapton.<ref name=RSGG/> Critics, however, often pointed to how safe they felt Mayer's music was. Chris Richards, in a review of a 2017 concert, declared Mayer is "an amazing guitar player", albeit doing so "through clenched teeth". Richards went on to say that his talent as a guitarist did not make him exempt from criticism of "his pillow-soft songcraft, the dull sentimentality of his lyrics, or that cuckoo-racist interview he gave to Playboy back in 2010".<ref name="richards">{{cite news |last1=Richards |first1=Chris |title=He's a stellar guitarist, but his songs are staid |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=April 7, 2017}}</ref> Music writer Steve Baltin commented on this dichotomy, saying that Mayer is "one of the sharpest and savviest musical minds you will ever encounter", and added: "While many have found reasons to dislike Mayer since the beginning of his career, he is a consummate musician's musician, an artist who has been embraced by Eric Clapton, [[Stevie Wonder]] and Buddy Guy among others."<ref name="baltin">{{cite web |last1=Baltin |first1=Steve |title=Why John Mayer Is Music's Forgotten Superstar |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevebaltin/2017/04/22/why-john-mayer-is-musics-forgotten-superstar/ |website=Forbes |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=April 22, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016083518/https://www.forbes.com/sites/stevebaltin/2017/04/22/why-john-mayer-is-musics-forgotten-superstar/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>

Mayer's inclusion in the line-up of Dead & Company was criticised by [[Chris Robinson (singer)|Chris Robinson]] of [[The Black Crowes]], who had previously played several shows with The Grateful Dead. Speaking during an interview with [[Howard Stern]], Robinson was quoted as saying that "everything that [[Jerry Garcia]] ever talked about or stood for, John Mayer is the antithesis", and that while "Jerry was one of the most unique musicians in the world [...] here's John Mayer playing everyone else's licks".<ref name="leenewcomb">{{cite web |last1=Lee Newcomb |first1=Ming |title=Chris Robinson Had Some Harsh Words For Both John Mayer And His Brother On Howard Stern |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/chris-robinson-howard-stern/ |website=L4LM |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=May 16, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016164929/https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/chris-robinson-howard-stern/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref> In response, Mayer said in an interview with ''Rolling Stone'' that he "care[s] about this band too much to give that [comment] life", and that he was "done debating [his] own merits."<ref name="ming">{{cite web |last1=Lee Newcomb |first1=Ming |title=John Mayer Addresses Chris Robinson's Criticisms In New Interview |url=https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-chris-robinsons-criticisms/ |website=L4LM |access-date=October 16, 2018 |date=June 28, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181016164918/https://liveforlivemusic.com/news/john-mayer-chris-robinsons-criticisms/ |archive-date=October 16, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>

== Personal life ==
[[File:John_Mayer_and_Family_at_his_40th_Birthday_Dinner.pdf|thumb|alt=Alt|Mayer celebrates his 40th birthday party with (left to right) his brother Ben, his sister Rachel, his father Dick, and his brother Carl.]]

On his third episode of ''Current Mood'', Mayer revealed he had been sober since 2016.<ref name=Catucci /> He stopped drinking after having what he says was a six-day hangover after [[Drake (musician)|Drake]]'s 30th birthday party.<ref name="drake">{{cite web |last1= Michaud |first1= Sarah |title= John Mayer Quit Drinking After Making 'Quite a Fool of Myself' at Drake's 30th Birthday Party |url=https://people.com/music/john-mayer-quit-drinking-after-drake-birthday-party/ |website=PEOPLE.com |access-date=November 27, 2018 |language=en |date=November 12, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181127195233/https://people.com/music/john-mayer-quit-drinking-after-drake-birthday-party/ |archive-date=November 27, 2018 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Mayer maintains close relationships with his father and siblings and embraces a domestic role when he is not on tour.<ref>{{cite web|last=Savino|first=Jessi|title=John Mayer Talks Life on the Road, Latest Album |url=https://huntnewsnu.com/5513/campus/john-mayer-talks-life-on-the-road-latest-album/|website=[[The Huntington News]]|access-date=July 19, 2022|date=February 3, 2007}}</ref>

Mayer was a friend of the late comedian and actor [[Bob Saget]], and when Saget unexpectedly died in an [[Orlando, Florida]] hotel room in January 2022, Mayer had Saget's body flown back to [[Los Angeles]] on a private jet.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.etonline.com/john-mayer-paid-for-a-private-plane-to-fly-bob-sagets-body-to-california-after-his-death-in-florida | title=John Mayer Paid for a Private Plane to Fly Bob Saget's Body to California After His Death in Florida &#124; Entertainment Tonight | date=January 20, 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://people.com/tv/john-mayer-paid-for-private-plane-to-fly-bob-sagets-body-to-california-after-his-death-in-florida/ | title=John Mayer Paid for Private Plane to Fly Bob Saget's Body to California After His Death in Florida | newspaper=People }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.complex.com/pop-culture/john-mayer-covered-cost-of-private-plane-to-transport-bob-saget-body-to-california | title=John Mayer Covered Cost of Private Plane to Transport Bob Saget's Body to California | website=[[Complex Networks]] }}</ref> Likewise, he and [[Jeff Ross]] retrieved Saget's car, which was parked at [[Los Angeles International Airport]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Travis |first1=Emily |title=How John Mayer Helped Return Bob Saget's Body to California After His Death |url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1317021/how-john-mayer-helped-return-bob-sagets-body-to-california-after-his-death |website=eonline.com |access-date=July 22, 2022 |date=January 20, 2022}}</ref>

=== Philanthropy ===
In 2002, Mayer created the "Back to You" Fund, a nonprofit organization that focuses on fundraising in the areas of health care, education, the arts and talent development. The foundation auctions exclusive John Mayer items, such as guitar picks, T-shirts and signed CDs. The auctions have been successful, with some tickets selling for more than 17 times their face value.<ref>[http://www.johnmayerauction.com/ The Official John Mayer Auction Site], John Mayer Auction. Retrieved April 23, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150131215549/http://www.johnmayerauction.com/ |date=January 31, 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businesshere.com/jmayer_success.htm |title= John Mayer| work= Business Here| access-date= April 23, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204233903/http://www.businesshere.com/jmayer_success.htm |archive-date= February 4, 2007 }}</ref>

Mayer participated at the [[Live Earth concert, New York City|East Rutherford, New Jersey]], location of the [[Live Earth]] project, a musical rally to support awareness for [[climate change]] held July 7, 2007.<ref>{{cite news| last= Kilgore| first= Kim |year= 2007|url=http://www.livedaily.com/news/More_cities_added_to_John_Mayers_itinerary-11983.html?t=1 |title= More cities added to John Mayer's itinerary| access-date= May 1, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215114914/http://www.livedaily.com/news/More_cities_added_to_John_Mayers_itinerary-11983.html?t=1 |archive-date=February 15, 2009 }}</ref>

Mayer performed at a number of benefits and telethons for charity throughout his career. He has participated in benefits for the [[Elton John AIDS Foundation]].<ref>{{cite journal| last= Adato| first= Allison| display-authors= 1 | date= April 7, 2003| title= Sweet Charity| journal= People | author2= other| volume= 59| number= 13| page= 87}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last= Gardner| first= Elysa |date= November 4, 2005| title= Celebrities share Elton John's vision| work= USA Today}}</ref> In response to the [[Virginia Tech shooting]], Mayer (along with [[Dave Matthews Band]], [[Phil Vassar]], and [[Nas]]) performed a free concert at Virginia Tech's [[Lane Stadium]] on September 6, 2007.<ref name=vt.edu>{{cite web| publisher= Virginia Tech | date= August 1, 2006|url=http://www.vt.edu/concert/ |title= A Concert For Virginia Tech| website= VT.edu| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823205848/http://www.vt.edu/concert/ |archive-date= August 23, 2007 }}</ref> followed by an appearance with [[Rob Thomas (musician)|Rob Thomas]] at the Annual Holiday Concert at [[Blythedale Children's Hospital]] in Valhalla that winter.<ref>{{cite news| date= January 7, 2008| title= Fly on the wall| work= Westchester County Business Journal| volume= 47| number= 1| page= 38}}</ref> On December 8, 2007, Mayer hosted the first annual Charity Revue, a tradition he has continued each year. Charities who have benefited from the concerts include [[Toys for Tots]], Inner City Arts and the Los Angeles Mission.<ref name=announce>{{cite web|url=http://www.johnmayer.com/news#4 |title= New Show: 1st Annual Holiday Charity Revue on December 8 at Nokia Theatre LA Live| last= Mayer| first= John | website= JohnMayer.com | publisher= John Mayer| date= November 14, 2007| access-date= December 29, 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226035537/http://johnmayer.com/news#4| archive-date=December 26, 2007|url-status=dead}}</ref> CDs and DVDs of the first concert were released as ''Where the Light Is'' in July 2008.<ref name="RS where the light is"/><ref name="billboard blackberry"/> Mayer appeared on ''[[Songs for Tibet: The Art of Peace]]'', a celebrity initiative to support [[Tibet]] and the 14th [[Dalai Lama]], [[14th Dalai Lama|Tenzin Gyatso]].<ref>{{cite news| last= Finn| first= Natalie | date= July 22, 2008|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/3342/sting-matthews-mayer-gamer-for-tibet-than-beijing |title= Sting, Matthews, Mayer Gamer for Tibet Than Beijing| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403093555/http://www.eonline.com/news/3342/sting-matthews-mayer-gamer-for-tibet-than-beijing |archive-date= April 3, 2015 | publisher= E!| website= eonline.com| access-date= March 25, 2015}}</ref> Mayer (along with Keith Urban) headlined Tiger Jam 2011 in Las Vegas to help raise around $750,000 for the [[Tiger Woods Foundation]].<ref>{{cite press release| date= May 2, 2011| title= John Mayer, Keith Urban Help Tiger Woods Raise Approximately $750,000 for the Tiger Woods Foundation at the 2011 Tiger Jam| publisher= PRNewswire}}</ref> In January 2013, Mayer participated with [[Zac Brown Band|Zac Brown]] in a benefit concert in [[Bozeman, Montana]] where they raised more than $100,000 for firefighters who battled a wildfire in the summer of 2012 in [[Paradise Valley (Montana)|Paradise Valley]] that destroyed 12,000 acres.<ref name= "benefitconcert"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Benoit|first=Zach|title=Pine Creek fire at 12,000 acres; at least 5 homes lost |url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/pine-creek-fire-at-acres-at-least-homes-lost/article_d8f8826d-beb7-5fbf-a43b-b76efa505246.html| work=Billings Gazette |access-date=February 18, 2013 |date=August 31, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704031555/http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/montana/pine-creek-fire-at-acres-at-least-homes-lost/article_d8f8826d-beb7-5fbf-a43b-b76efa505246.html|archive-date=July 4, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref>

On March 1, 2019, Mayer established the Heart and Armor Foundation in support of veterans of war.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heartandarmor.org/|title=Heart And Armor Foundation|website=Heartandarmor.org}}</ref> He has been actively involved in initiatives to help returning veterans for about 12 years.<ref>{{cite magazine |first=Jon |last=Blistein |date=March 1, 2019 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/john-mayer-heart-and-armor-foundation-veterans-802243/ |title=John Mayer Launches Heart and Armor Foundation to Aid Veterans |magazine=Rolling Stone |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |agency=Associated Press |date=March 2, 2019 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2019/03/02/john-mayer-launches-foundation-focused-improving-veterans-health/3039035002/ |title=John Mayer Launches Foundation Focused on Improving the Health Of Veterans |work= USA Today |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Sarah |last=Michaud |date=March 1, 2019 |url=https://people.com/music/john-mayer-launches-heart-and-armor-foundation/ |title=John Mayer Launches Heart and Armor Foundation: 'We Can All Do a Better Job of Sharing the Burden' |website=People |access-date=May 30, 2020}}</ref>

===Controversies===
Mayer's relationship with Jessica Simpson coincided with behavior changes that significantly increased his [[tabloid journalism|tabloid]] exposure.<ref name=Playboy/><ref name=Mather/><ref name=ownwordsone>{{cite magazine| date= January 22, 2010 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-in-his-own-words-20100122 | title= John Mayer in His Own Words |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170827131048/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-in-his-own-words-20100122 |archive-date= August 27, 2017| magazine= Rolling Stone| access-date= March 25, 2015}}</ref> Early in his career, he had expressed his resolve to completely avoid drugs, alcohol, [[Nightclub|clubbing]], "[[Red carpet|red-carpet]]" events, dating celebrities, and anything that he felt would detract the focus from his music.<ref name=guthrie>{{cite news| last= Guthrie| first= Blake |date= May 16, 2001|url=https://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/content-159632-Square-pegged |title= Square pegged |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070204095109/http://atlanta.creativeloafing.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A4733 |archive-date=February 4, 2007 | work= Creative Loafing| access-date= February 2, 2010}}</ref> In later interviews Mayer alluded to experiencing an extreme "anxiety bender" episode in his twenties that motivated him to be less reclusive.<ref name=Hedegaard/><ref name=Mather/> In 2006, he first mentioned that he had begun using [[marijuana]].<ref name="RS06" /> He began making appearances at clubs in Los Angeles and New York City, and Simpson became the first in a string of famous girlfriends, including [[Jennifer Aniston]] and [[Minka Kelly]].<ref name=eastland/> By 2007, his personal life had become regular fodder for the [[Tabloid journalism|gossip media]] and, as a result, Mayer made efforts to control his public image. His online presence increased,{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} he began to stage pranks for the paparazzi,<ref>{{cite journal| last= Garcia| first= Jennifer |date= June 15, 2009 |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20285171,00.html |title= John Mayer Performs, Fakes Pal's Hospital Trip| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907005741/http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20285171,00.html |archive-date= September 7, 2015 | journal= People| access-date= April 28, 2015}}</ref> and he hosted a segment for the gossip show ''[[TMZ]]''.<ref>{{cite news| date= August 5, 2008|url=https://huffingtonpost.com/2008/07/28/john-mayer-guest-hosts-tm_n_115406.html |title= John Mayer TMZ Video: 'Am I Really A Celebrity?' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402121122/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/07/28/john-mayer-guest-hosts-tm_n_115406.html |archive-date= April 2, 2015 | work= Huffington Post |access-date= March 19, 2015}}</ref>

{{quote box|width=350px|align=right|quote=I abused that ability to express myself, to the point where I was expressing things that weren't true to my thoughts.<ref name=patrickdoyle/>|source=John Mayer, ''Rolling Stone'' interview, January 2013}}
In early 2010, Mayer gave a controversial interview to ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine<ref name=outrage>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1631667/john-mayers-playboy-interview-causes-uproar-online.jhtml|title=John Mayer's Playboy Interview Causes Uproar Online|date=February 10, 2010|publisher=MTV|access-date=July 24, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629112033/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1631667/john-mayers-playboy-interview-causes-uproar-online.jhtml|archive-date=June 29, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> in which he revealed sexually explicit details about his former girlfriends Jessica Simpson and Jennifer Aniston—calling his relationship with the former "sexual napalm".<ref>{{Cite web|date=April 12, 2010|title=John Mayer: Jessica Simpson Is "Sexual Napalm," Jennifer Aniston Hates Twitter|url=https://www.huffpost.com/entry/john-mayer-jessica-simpso_n_456566|access-date=September 16, 2021|website=HuffPost|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Peppin|first=Hayley|title=Jessica Simpson said she was 'floored and embarrassed' after John Mayer called her 'sexual napalm'|url=https://www.insider.com/jessica-simpson-was-floored-after-john-mayer-called-her-sexual-napalm-2020-1|access-date=September 16, 2021|website=Insider|language=en-US}}</ref> In response to a question about whether black women were interested in him, he said, "My dick is sort of like a white supremacist. I've got a Benetton heart and a fuckin' [[David Duke]] cock. I'm going to start dating separately from my dick."<ref name=Playboy>{{cite web|title=Playboy Interview: John Mayer|date=February 10, 2010|url=http://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-john-mayer|work=Playboy|access-date=February 10, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140831080718/http://www.playboy.com/articles/playboy-interview-john-mayer|archive-date=August 31, 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref> He also used the word "[[nigger]]" in the interview. This set off accusations in the media of him being a [[Misogyny|misogynist]], [[wikt:kiss-and-tell|kiss-and-tell]] ex-boyfriend, and [[Racism|racist]].<ref>Herrera, Monica (February 10, 2010). [https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959433/john-mayers-sexually-racially-charged-playboy-interview-sparks-outrage "John Mayer's Sexually, Racially Charged Playboy Interview Sparks Outrage"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130219085115/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959433/john-mayers-sexually-racially-charged-playboy-interview-sparks-outrage |date=February 19, 2013 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved February 10, 2010.</ref> He apologized via Twitter for his use of the word "nigger", saying, "It was arrogant of me to think I could intellectualize...a word that is so emotionally charged".<ref>Herrera, Monica (February 10, 2010), [https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959424/john-mayer-apologizes-for-using-racial-slur-in-playboy-interview "Playboy Interview] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705104645/http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959424/john-mayer-apologizes-for-using-racial-slur-in-playboy-interview |date=July 5, 2015 }}. ''Billboard''. Retrieved March 23, 2015.</ref> He also tearfully apologized to his band and fans at his concert in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] later that night.<ref>{{cite AV media | date = February 10, 2010 | title = John Mayer Cries/Apologizes in Nashville, TN 10 February 2010 Sommet Center | medium = Concert footage |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x765IhCvnqg | access-date = March 19, 2015 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017085446/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x765IhCvnqg | archive-date = October 17, 2015 | url-status=live }}</ref> In the following two years, he left New York and retreated from the media.<ref name=sniping/> Reflecting on that time in a May 2012 episode of ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', he said: <blockquote>"I lost my head for a little while and I did a couple of dumb interviews and it kind of woke me up...It was a violent crash into being an adult. For a couple of years, it was just figuring it all out, and I'm glad I actually stayed out of the spotlight."<ref name="ellen">{{cite web|title=John Mayer on Taking a Break|url=http://ellen.warnerbros.com/2012/05/john_mayer_on_taking_a_break_0515.php|website=Warner Bros|access-date=June 12, 2012|date=May 15, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617205210/http://ellen.warnerbros.com/2012/05/john_mayer_on_taking_a_break_0515.php|archive-date=June 17, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chen|first=Joyce|title=John Mayer: 'I lost my head for a while'|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-05-15/news/31714265_1_john-mayer-spotlight-interviews|work=Daily News|location=New York|access-date=June 12, 2012|date=May 15, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028212158/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2012-05-15/news/31714265_1_john-mayer-spotlight-interviews|archive-date=October 28, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Koonse |first=Emma |title=John Mayer 'Lost His Head' 2 Years Ago |url=http://global.christianpost.com/news/john-mayer-lost-his-head-2-years-ago-75026/ |work=The Christian Post |access-date=June 12, 2012 |date=May 16, 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130406091215/http://global.christianpost.com/news/john-mayer-lost-his-head-2-years-ago-75026/ |archive-date=April 6, 2013 }}</ref></blockquote>

Singer-songwriter [[Taylor Swift]] performed vocals for the song "[[Half of My Heart]]" on Mayer's November 2009 album ''[[Battle Studies (album)|Battle Studies]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|title=John Mayer Talks Taylor Swift Collaboration 'Half of My Heart'|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1625724/john-mayer-talks-taylor-swift-collaboration-half-my-heart.jhtml|website=MTV|access-date=June 11, 2012|date=November 6, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414193121/http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1625724/john-mayer-talks-taylor-swift-collaboration-half-my-heart.jhtml|archive-date=April 14, 2012|url-status=dead}}</ref> Rumors began to circulate in the media that the two were a couple, an assertion that neither addressed. However, Swift released a song called "[[Dear John (Taylor Swift song)|Dear John]]" in 2010, which was widely believed to be about her relationship with him. In June 2012, Mayer criticized the song, saying she never contacted him and that "it's abusing your talent to rub your hands together and go, 'Wait till he gets a load of this!'"<ref>{{cite magazine|title=John Mayer: Taylor Swift's 'Dear John' Song 'Humiliated Me'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-taylor-swifts-dear-john-song-humiliated-me-20120606|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=June 6, 2012|date=June 11, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623203359/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/john-mayer-taylor-swifts-dear-john-song-humiliated-me-20120606|archive-date=June 23, 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> The song "Paper Doll" was reported to be a [[answer song|response]].<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/06/taylor-swift-paper-doll-photos_slideshow_item0_1|title=Photos: Five Reasons to Think Taylor Swift Is John Mayer's "Paper Doll"|date=June 19, 2013|author=Julie Miller|magazine=Vanity Fair|access-date=August 9, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806084246/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/oscars/2013/06/taylor-swift-paper-doll-photos_slideshow_item0_1|archive-date=August 6, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> In the March 21, 2019, episode of ''Current Mood'', however, Mayer said: <blockquote>"When 'Paper Doll' came out, 100% of the people believed it was about somebody...But the song was not about that person and I could never tell anybody, 'That's not true,' because then I would be breaking my rule that songwriters don't say who the songs are about or not about."<ref>{{cite AV media | people =JOhn Mayer | date =March 21, 2019 | title =Current Mood from Brisbane, Australia—John Mayer World Tour 2019 | medium =webshow | time =23m40s | location =Brisbane, Australia | publisher =Instagram }}</ref></blockquote>

In March 2014, Mayer sued watch dealer Robert Maron for $656,000 when he discovered that seven of the $5 million in watches he purchased from the dealer contained counterfeit parts.<ref>''People'' staff (March 29, 2014), "THE Action". ''Billboard''. '''126''' (11):3</ref><ref>James (March 20, 2014), [http://www.theversatilegent.com/the-horology-world-holds-its-breath-over-john-mayer-fake-watch-story/ "The Horology World Holds Its BreathOver John Mayer Fake Watch Story"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402181736/http://www.theversatilegent.com/the-horology-world-holds-its-breath-over-john-mayer-fake-watch-story/ |date=April 2, 2015 }}. Retrieved March 24, 2015.</ref> He dropped the action in May 2015, releasing a statement that asserted that research restored his "belief that Bob Maron is an expert on Rolex watches and confirmed that Bob Maron never sold him a counterfeit watch."<ref name="WOLF">{{cite web |last1=WOLF |first1=CAMERON |title=John Mayer Admits He Was Wrong About Potentially Fake $600,000 Rolex Collection |url=https://www.complex.com/style/2015/05/john-mayer-drops-fake-rolex-lawsuit |website=Complex |access-date=June 23, 2019 |language=en |date=May 21, 2015}}</ref>

== Notes ==
{{refbegin}}
{{cnote|a|Generally, it was believed that Mayer's father, a [[Central High School (Connecticut)|Bridgeport High School]] principal, had given him a tape player (confiscated from a student) that happened to contain [[Stevie Ray Vaughan]] album. However, in a 2006 interview on the New Zealand show ''[[Close Up (TV programme)|Close Up]]'' (and other interviews), Mayer said that this was not true.<ref name=CU/>}}
{{cnote|b|"Bittersweet Poetry" was released in the summer of 2007 (three years after its creation) as an iTunes pre-order bonus track to the album ''[[Graduation (album)|Graduation]]''.}}
{{cnote|c|The quote is taken from the posthumously-published book ''[[Battle Studies]]'' by Colonel [[Ardant Du Picq]] (d. 1870)}}
{{refend}}

'''John R. Cash''' (born '''J. R. Cash'''; February 26, 1932 – September 12, 2003) was an American singer-songwriter. Most of Cash's music contains themes of sorrow, moral tribulation, and redemption, especially songs from the later stages of his career.<ref name="Parales" /><ref name="Mulligan">{{Citation|last=Mulligan|first=J.|title=Johnny Cash: American VI: Ain't No Grave|date=February 24, 2010|url=http://entertainment.ie/album-review/Johnny-Cash--American-VI-Ain%27t-No-Grave/6891.htm|website=Entertainment.ie|type=album review|access-date=March 22, 2010}}</ref> He was known for his deep, calm, [[bass-baritone]] voice,{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|Although Cash's [[voice type]] endured over the years, his [[timbre]] changed noticeably. Pareles writes: "Through a recording career that stretches back to 1955, Cash's bass-baritone voice has gone from gravelly to grave."<ref name="Parales">{{cite news |last1=Pareles |first1=Jon |title=Pop Review; Johnny Cash, Austerely Direct From Deep Within |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/16/arts/pop-review-johnny-cash-austerely-direct-from-deep-within.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 26, 2019 |date=September 16, 1994}}</ref>}}{{Sfn|Urbanski|2003|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=x_dK-0HfHUYC xiv]}} the distinctive sound of his backing band, [[the Tennessee Three]], that was characterized by its train-like chugging guitar rhythms, a rebelliousness<ref name="Dickie">{{Cite book|last=Dickie|first=M.|url=https://archive.org/details/ringoffire00mich|title=Ring of fire: The Johnny Cash reader|publisher=Da Capo|year=2002|isbn=9780306811227|editor-last=Streissguth|editor-first=M.|place=Cambridge, MA|pages=[https://archive.org/details/ringoffire00mich/page/201 201]–205|contribution=Hard talk from the God-fearin', pro-metal man in Black|orig-year=1987|url-access=registration}}</ref><ref name="Streissguth_profile">{{Cite book|last=Streissguth|first=M.|url=https://archive.org/details/johnnycashbiogra00stre_0|title=Johnny Cash: a biography|publisher=Da Capo|year=2006|isbn=9780306813689|place=Philadelphia, PA|page=[https://archive.org/details/johnnycashbiogra00stre_0/page/196 196]|url-access=registration}}</ref> coupled with an increasingly somber and humble demeanor,<ref name="Parales" /> and his free prison concerts.<ref name="Fox">{{Citation|last=Fox|first=JA|title=Hard time's never a 'circus'|date=October 17, 2005|url=http://www.baylor.edu/pr/bitn/news.php?action=story&story=37416|newspaper=The Boston Herald|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060920020148/http://www.baylor.edu/pr/bitn/news.php?action=story&story=37416|publisher=[[Baylor University]]|access-date=March 22, 2010|archive-date=September 20, 2006|url-status=dead}}</ref> Cash wore a trademark all-black stage wardrobe, which earned him the [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|nickname]] "[[Man in Black (song)|Man in Black]]".{{Refn|group="lower-alpha"|For Cash, black stage attire was a "symbol of rebellion—against a stagnant status quo, against&nbsp;... hypocritical houses of God, against people whose minds are closed to others' ideas".<ref name="Page 64"/>}}

Born to poor cotton farmers in [[Kingsland, Arkansas]], Cash grew up on gospel music and played on a local radio station in high school. He served four years in the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], much of it in West Germany. After his return to the United States, he rose to fame during the mid-1950s in the burgeoning [[rockabilly]] scene in [[Memphis, Tennessee]]. He traditionally began his concerts by introducing himself with "Hello, I'm Johnny Cash".{{Refn|group="lower-alpha" | Schultz refers to this phrase as Cash's "trademark greeting", and places his utterance of this line, on Cash's ''[[At Folsom Prison]]'' album, "among the most electrifying [seconds] in the history of concert recording."<ref name="Schultz">{{Citation|last=Schultz|first=B.|date=July 1, 2000|url=http://mixonline.com/mag/audio_classic_tracks_johnny|title=Classic Tracks: Johnny Cash's 'Folsom Prison Blues' |newspaper=[[Mix (magazine)|Mix]]|access-date=March 22, 2010|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102091058/http://mixonline.com/mag/audio_classic_tracks_johnny/|archive-date=January 2, 2010}}</ref>}} He began to follow that by "[[Folsom Prison Blues]]", one of his [[signature song]]s. His other signature songs include "[[I Walk the Line]]", "[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]", "[[Get Rhythm]]", and "[[Man in Black (song)|Man in Black]]".
